He didn’t look at Aksel. “I find that hard to believe. Solicitors are cautious. They file paperwork. They don’t send engraved invitations to their own executions.”

Aksel’s blood turned to ice, but he kept his head bent over his notebook. “I was just looking for some inspiration,” he replied, his voice a low tremor. “A song about love and heartbreak.” Finch chuckled, a dry, rustling sound. “Ondine. A tragic water nymph who cursed her unfaithful lover to a waking death. A rather obscure and aggressive choice of heartbreak, wouldn't you say? Especially for a man who is supposed to remember nothing.” He finally turned, and his eyes, a pale, washed-out blue, were devoid of all emotion. They were the eyes of a man looking at a problem to be solved, not a person to be killed. “Koskinen is sentimental. He saw an opportunity to keep a useful asset on the books. I advised against it. Loose ends should be tied, not repurposed. It seems my initial assessment was correct.” He took a step closer. From the inside pocket of his suit jacket, he produced a slim object that looked like a fountain pen. He clicked the top. A needle, less than an inch long and glistening with a clear fluid, emerged from the tip with a faint, metallic *snick*. “Fentanyl, mixed with a potassium chloride solution. Quick. Quiet. It will look like a simple, tragic cardiac event. The tortured artist, overwhelmed by the pressures of fame. The media will write your eulogy for you.”

Aksel’s body was frozen, his mind screaming. He looked past Finch, desperately searching for a sign of Croft’s team. The garden was empty. The trap had failed. He was alone with his executioner. Finch took another step, raising the pen. “A shame,” he said conversationally. “You have a remarkable voice.”

It was then that the gardener in the high-vis jacket, who had been silently working his way along the far wall, stood up. At the same moment, the young couple who had been whispering by the fountain also rose, their romantic facade evaporating. They moved in a silent, coordinated triangle, their movements fluid and economical. Finch sensed the shift in the atmosphere an instant before it happened. He started to turn, his professional calm finally cracking, the needle swinging towards the new threats. He was too late. The gardener was impossibly fast. He closed the distance in two silent strides, his arm lashing out not with a trowel, but with a thin, black garrote wire. The wire looped over Finch’s head, snapping tight around his throat. The woman from the couple stepped in, her hand striking Finch’s wrist with brutal precision, sending the needle pen clattering to the flagstones. The other man kicked the back of Finch’s knees, buckling his legs. The entire takedown was over in less than three seconds. It was utterly silent, brutally efficient, and horrifying to watch.

Finch didn’t even have time to struggle. He was bundled backwards, half-dragged, half-carried, through a low, previously unnoticed door in the ancient stone wall, a door that had been hidden behind a thick curtain of ivy. The door closed, and they were gone. Aksel was left sitting on the bench, his heart trying to hammer its way out of his chest, the silent scream still lodged in his throat. A moment later, Julian Croft stepped out from behind a thick yew tree, looking as calm and unruffled as if he had just been admiring the foliage. He walked over and picked up the needle pen with a handkerchief, examining it with detached curiosity before pocketing it. “Excellent. Punctual and efficient. I do hate a fuss.” He looked at Aksel’s ashen face. “Breathe, Ari. The hard part is over. For now.” Croft handed him the burner phone. “Go back to your camera crew. Tell them the muse has provided her inspiration. You have a television show to win.” He gave a thin, bloodless smile. “After all, you’re a national treasure now.” Then he, too, turned and walked away, disappearing down a side path, leaving Aksel alone in the sudden, deafening silence of the ruined garden.## Chapter 10

It took a full minute for Aksel’s legs to obey him. He sat on the cold stone bench, the silence of the garden a roaring in his ears, his gaze fixed on the ivy-covered wall that had swallowed three men and a brutal act of violence whole. His mind, the solicitor’s mind, was trying to process the event, to file it under a known category, but there was none. He had just witnessed a man being professionally disappeared, seconds after that same man had been poised to murder him with a fountain pen. His body was a chaos of post-adrenaline tremors, his hands shaking so violently he had to clench them into fists to still them. He was alive. The thought was not triumphant; it was a staggering, bewildering fact.

He forced himself to his feet, his muscles stiff and uncooperative. He had to walk back to the camera crew. He had to be Aksel Virtanen, the pensive artist, not Ari Virtanen, the man who had just served as human bait. He took a deep, shuddering breath and started the slow walk back towards the entrance. He focused on the mechanics of it: left foot, right foot. He schooled his features into a mask of weary introspection, hoping it would be mistaken for artistic immersion. Steve, the cameraman, was packing away a lens case, his expression one of pure, unadulterated boredom. He looked up as Aksel approached.

"Alright, mate? Got what you needed?" Steve asked, his voice a gravelly monotone. "You look like you've seen a ghost." The casual accuracy of the remark sent a jolt of icy fear through Aksel, but he managed a slow, tired nod. "Something like that," he murmured, his voice hoarse. "It’s a powerful place. I think… I think I have the song now." The cameraman grunted, accepting the explanation without question. To him, Aksel was just another piece of high-maintenance talent, prone to fits of dramatic melancholy. The profound, life-altering violence that had just occurred ten yards away was utterly invisible to him, a different dimension of reality. The sheer banality of the crew’s conversation as they packed him into the car was a form of psychological torture, a dissonant soundtrack playing over the silent scream in his mind.

Back in the anonymous safety of his hotel room, the facade crumbled. He locked the door and leaned against it, his legs finally giving way as he slid to the floor. The image of the garrote wire, of Finch’s eyes widening in a brief, final moment of professional surprise, was burned onto the inside of his eyelids. He had been complicit. He had led a man to a trap where he was ambushed and abducted. It didn't matter that the man was a killer who had been about to end his life; the cold, transactional nature of the event left a stain on him. He was no longer just a victim. He was a player in their savage game, his hands stained with the same ink. The burner phone vibrated in his pocket. He fumbled for it, his fingers clumsy and numb. It was a message from Croft. *Asset secured. Awaiting debrief. You performed well. Lie low.* The message was as cold and efficient as the takedown itself. He had performed well. He was the star of the show, in more ways than one.

The next day, he walked into his session with Ricardo like a man returning from a war. The haunted, anxious quality that had defined him was gone, replaced by a hollow-eyed stillness, the quiet of a man who has looked into the abyss and seen it blink first. He placed a new sheet of music on the piano. "Waterloo Sunset". Ricardo looked at the title, then up at Aksel's face, his gaze sharp and deeply knowing. He didn't ask about the ruined church. He didn’t need to. He could see the ruins in Aksel's eyes. "Ah," Ricardo said softly, a world of understanding in the single syllable. "The song you lied about. A song about watching the world from a safe distance, feeling beautifully sad. A survivor’s song." He turned to the piano and began to play, the familiar, gentle melody filling the room. He didn’t coach. He accompanied. He followed Aksel’s lead as he sang, his voice no longer raw with anger or fear, but imbued with a profound, weary melancholy, the sound of a man who had paid an unbearable price for the view from the bridge.

While Aksel sang of sunsets, Julian Croft was at work. Finch, a professional conditioned by a lifetime of knowing when a game was lost, was proving to be a wealth of information. Another message arrived on the burner phone that evening. *Finch is talking. His network is being dismantled as we speak. Koskinen is blind in London, and he knows it. He's panicking. He will view you not as a threat, but as his only remaining link to his UK operation. He will try to contact you. Do not answer any calls from unknown Finnish numbers. The final phase is approaching. The grand final.* The message was a shot of pure adrenaline. Koskinen was cornered. A cornered animal was the most dangerous kind. Aksel knew, with a dreadful certainty, that Koskinen would not try to reach him through a sterile, deniable phone call. He would use a weapon that was far more intimate.

The call came the next evening. It came not to the burner phone, but to the official X-Factor mobile that Chloe had given him. The screen lit up with the name he both longed for and dreaded: ‘Äiti’. His mother. His hand trembled as he answered, a cold knot of fear tightening in his stomach. Her voice, when it came, was thin and strained, a pale imitation of its usual warmth. "Akseli? Rakas, it’s me." He could hear the forced brightness, the terror humming just beneath the surface. He knew instantly that she was not alone. Koskinen was in the room with her. He was standing over her, his presence a poison in the air between them. "Äiti, what is it? Is everything alright?" he asked, playing his part, his voice full of a love and concern that was agonizingly real.

"Everything is fine, wonderful," she said, her voice unnaturally high. "Mr. Koskinen is here. He’s been so kind. He’s worried about you, Akseli. We both are. This… this silly show. It’s too much for you. You sound so tired. We think you should come home." It was a plea and a command, her words a script written by the man holding her hostage. "Mr. Koskinen has arranged everything. He can have a car waiting for you at the airport. You can just leave. Forget all this nonsense. Come home to us. Please, Akseli. I miss you so much." A small, choked sob escaped her, a sound so genuine and full of pain that it felt like a physical blow.

He closed his eyes, the image of his mother’s terrified face filling his mind. This was the final test. Koskinen was using his last, most valuable weapon. To agree would be to walk directly into his captor’s arms, to invalidate everything he had sacrificed, to render Finch's capture meaningless. To refuse would be to tighten the screw on his mother, to leave her in the hands of a desperate, cornered monster. He thought of Croft's plan, of the final, decisive trap that needed to be set. There was only one path forward. He had to sever the connection. He had to abandon his mother to save her.

"I can't, Äiti," he said, his voice quiet, steady, and devastatingly calm. The words tasted like glass in his mouth. "I have to finish what I started. This is important. But I will see you soon. I promise." He poured every ounce of love and reassurance he could muster into that final promise. Before she could reply, before Koskinen could force another word from her, he ended the call. He sat in the silence of his room, the phone dead in his hand, the finality of his choice settling upon him like a shroud. He had refused the ransom. He had just dared the devil to do his worst. The board was set for the final move, and it would all play out on the stage of the X-Factor grand final.The silence that followed was more profound than any he had ever known. It was the silence of a bridge burned, a lifeline severed. He sat motionless, the dead phone a cold, useless weight in his hand. He had just condemned his mother to the company of her tormentor, armed only with the desperate, flimsy hope that his refusal would be seen as a sign of strength, a warning that he was no longer controllable. He felt the two halves of himself at war: Aksel, the son, was screaming in a silent agony of guilt and terror; Ari, the strategist, was coldly calculating the odds, marking the sacrifice as a necessary, brutal move in a game with no other rules.

Sleep was a distant country he could no longer visit. He spent the night staring at the ceiling, the city lights painting shifting patterns on the walls. He was a ghost in his own life, haunted by a past he couldn’t fully remember and a future he might not live to see. The victory over Finch felt hollow, a tactical skirmish in a war whose emotional cost was proving unbearable. Koskinen had escalated the conflict from the professional to the personal, and in doing so, had shown Aksel the true path to victory. To defeat Koskinen, he couldn't just expose the criminal; he had to destroy the man.

At dawn, he picked up the burner phone. His message to Croft was terse, devoid of the panic raging inside him. *'Contact made. Mother is hostage. He wants me to walk into the trap. I refused. Your move.'*

Croft’s reply came within minutes, as cool and immediate as a surgeon's diagnosis. *'Predictable escalation. He's using his final leverage. This is not a weakness. It's an opportunity. A cornered predator is reckless. We will use his desperation to force a rescue operation for your mother. He won't trust anyone else. He will have to expose his own operational command in Finland. The Grand Final is in three days. That is our stage.'*

The final week of the X-Factor was a hallucinatory blur. Aksel was one of two finalists, pitted against Leo, the soulful teenager whose journey had been one of innocent, wide-eyed wonder. The contrast was a narrative made in heaven for the producers. The Dark Horse versus the Nation's Sweetheart. The media frenzy was relentless. Aksel was trailed everywhere, his "tortured artist" persona now cemented in the public consciousness. He gave interviews in a near-catatonic state of emotional exhaustion, his vague, monosyllabic answers interpreted as profound depth rather than the soul-crushing terror they truly were.

He had one final meeting with Croft, a fleeting, two-minute encounter in the echoing stairwell of a multi-story car park. Croft looked at him, his pale grey eyes taking in Aksel's hollowed-out expression. "You are at your breaking point," he stated, not with sympathy, but with analytical approval. "Good. You will be believable." He handed Aksel a tiny, flesh-coloured earpiece, no bigger than a pea. "This is a one-way communication device. My team will be on the ground in Helsinki, near your mother's apartment building. When we are in position, I will give you the signal. Your performance will be the trigger. The moment the song ends, we move. Your job is to create the biggest, most emotional, most talked-about television event of the decade. Your performance must convince Koskinen of one thing: that you have completely broken down. That you are no longer a threat, but a pathetic, shattered man who is about to confess everything on live television. You will make him believe his only option is to silence you permanently, but first, he must secure his leverage—your mother—by moving her. The moment his men move her, my team takes them. And we get your mother."

"And the song?" Aksel asked, his voice a dry whisper. Croft gave a thin smile. "That, Ari, is up to the artist. Make it count."

There was only one choice. The song that had started it all. The raw, a cappella video he had sent on a whim, fuelled by cheap wine and a life of quiet desperation. The song that had summoned the ghost of Ari from his cage. "Hallelujah".

The night of the Grand Final was an explosion of light, sound, and manufactured hysteria. In the dressing room, Leo was bouncing on the balls of his feet, his face alight with pure, unadulterated joy. He was about to live his dream. Aksel sat in front of his own mirror, his face pale beneath the stage makeup, and carefully inserted the tiny earpiece. It was invisible. He was a soldier, wired for his final mission. He and Leo were called to the stage. They stood side-by-side as the host whipped the crowd into a frenzy. The voting lines were open. It was time for their final solo performances. Leo went first. He sang a soaring, triumphant ballad, his voice clear and full of youthful hope. He was flawless. The arena erupted in a storm of adoration. It was the performance of a winner.

Then it was Aksel's turn. He walked to the centre of the vast stage. There was no stool this time, no guitar. Just him, a microphone, and a single, stark spotlight. He nodded to the musical director, and a lone piano began to play the song's iconic, mournful arpeggio. He closed his eyes, not for effect, but to centre himself, to find the core of the man he had become. He was Aksel, the son who loved his mother. He was Ari, the bookkeeper who knew the crimes. He was the finalist, the national treasure, the bait. He was all of them. He took a breath, and the voice that came out was not a performance. It was a prayer.

He sang the opening verse with a heartbreaking fragility, the story of a secret chord, of a baffled king. He sang of love and loss, his voice cracking with a sorrow so real and profound that a hush fell over the entire arena. This was not the cold fury of his previous performances. This was the sound of a man utterly broken. This was for Koskinen. He sang the verses about seeing her bathing on the roof, her beauty and the moonlight overthrowing him. His voice swelled with a desperate, remembered passion, and he knew his mother, wherever she was, would understand he was singing about a love that could not be broken.

Then, as the song reached its emotional peak, he felt a faint crackle in his ear. Croft’s voice, a calm, disembodied whisper, cut through the music. *'We are in position. Koskinen's men are outside her door. He's taking the bait.'* The final verse. Aksel’s eyes snapped open, and he stared directly into the camera, into the soul of the machine. The fragility was gone, replaced by a terrifying, righteous fury. His voice soared, raw and powerful, no longer the sound of a broken man, but of an avenging angel. "I've told the truth, I didn't come to fool you," he sang, the words a direct accusation. "And even though it all went wrong / I'll stand before the Lord of Song / With nothing on my tongue but Hallelujah!" He held the final, monumental note, his body a conduit for every ounce of pain, rage, and hope from his impossible journey. He poured it all out, a single, sustained cry of defiance that seemed to shake the very foundations of the arena. He held it until his lungs burned, until the world dissolved into a blaze of white light, and then, as the note finally died, he fell to his knees, his head bowed, the sound of his own ragged breath the only thing left in the silence. It was done. The signal was sent.

parts.text:
The filing cabinet hummed. A low, monotonous thrum that vibrated through the cheap laminate flooring and up into the soles of Aksel Virtanen’s sensible leather shoes. It was the soundtrack to his life. A C-sharp of pure, unadulterated bureaucracy. From his desk on the third floor of Virtanen & Koskinen, a firm whose name carried far more gravitas than its actual legal footprint, Aksel could see a slice of Helsinki harbour. A sliver of gunmetal grey water, currently being pelted by a relentless November drizzle. Ferries, like fat, white ghosts, slipped in and out of the view, their horns a mournful bass note against the cabinet’s unyielding tenor.

Aksel aligned his pens. A silver fountain pen, a black rollerball, and a red biro for marking urgent amendments. They lay in a perfect, parallel formation on the green blotter, their metallic clips catching the weak, fluorescent light. Order. This was his sanctuary. In a world of messy divorces, contested wills, and the chaotic sprawl of contractual disputes, his desk was a tiny, controllable kingdom. He was a good solicitor. Meticulous. Reliable. His clients, mostly small business owners and bewildered inheritors of modest estates, appreciated his calm demeanour, his patient explanations of impenetrable legal jargon. They saw a man as steady and predictable as the Finnish seasons. They had no idea about the secret symphony that raged inside him.

The secret was a voice. A voice that felt like it belonged to someone else entirely. Someone bolder, someone who lived in a world of spotlights and applause, not billable hours and affidavits. At home, in the sterile quiet of his Kallio apartment, that voice was set free. It ricocheted off the bare white walls as he sang to backing tracks, his body electric with a current that his day job did everything to earth. He could be a rock god, a soul legend, a crooner from a bygone era. He could climb scales that scraped the sky and hold notes until his lungs burned with a glorious, fiery ache. The man who spent his days drafting clauses on riparian rights could, by night, channel the raw, heartbroken power of a Jeff Buckley or the soaring theatricality of a Freddie Mercury. It was a bizarre, thrilling dichotomy that he guarded with the same fierce precision he applied to his legal work.

The X-Factor audition had been a whim. A moment of madness during a particularly gruelling week finalising the sale of a small archipelago fishery. He’d seen an online advertisement for international applicants, a new gimmick for the British show. On a rain-lashed Tuesday night, fuelled by two glasses of cheap rioja and a profound sense of 'what if?', he had propped his phone against a stack of tort law textbooks, and sung. He’d poured all the frustration, all the quiet yearning of his meticulously ordered life, into a raw, a cappella rendition of "Hallelujah". He sent the video, deleted it immediately from his phone, and tried to forget the entire insane episode. He had, mostly. It was a foolish dream, a momentary crack in the sensible façade.

Until the envelope arrived. It wasn't brown and official-looking, like the rest of his mail. It was thick, creamy card, impossibly crisp. It lay on his doormat looking offensively glamorous. In the top left corner, a single, stark, silver 'X' was embossed. His heart, an organ usually as steady and reliable as a metronome, performed a frantic, unpractised drum solo against his ribs. This was a joke. It had to be. Probably from Antti, his cousin, who found Aksel’s quiet life a source of endless amusement.

His hands, usually so steady during delicate client negotiations, trembled as he slit the envelope open with a butter knife. The letterhead was real. The logo shimmered. The typeface was clean and impossibly professional. 'Dear Aksel Virtanen,' it began, the English words looking alien and exotic in his Helsinki apartment. 'Following your exceptional online audition and subsequent video call rounds, we are… delighted… to confirm your place as a finalist in this year’s X-Factor live shows.'

The butter knife clattered to the floor. Delighted. A word one used when a distant relative announced a surprisingly good engagement. They were *delighted*. He read the sentence again. And again. Finalist. Live shows. The words swam, refusing to lock into a coherent meaning. It felt like reading a legal document in a language he’d never studied. He sank onto the edge of his sofa, the expensive cardstock crinkling in his white-knuckled grip. A laugh escaped him, a strange, choked sound. Him. Aksel Virtanen. The man who alphabetised his spice rack. He was going to be on the X-Factor. A finalist. The absurdity of it was a physical blow, knocking the air from his lungs. For a full minute, he just sat there, the hum of the refrigerator taking over from the filing cabinet of his memory, the only sound in a world that had just tilted violently on its axis. Then, a slow, wide grin spread across his face, a genuine, uncalculated expression so rare it felt like stretching a long-dormant muscle. It wasn't a joke. It was real. And it was the most terrifying, most wonderful thing that had ever happened to him.

The next few days passed in a surreal blur. By day, he was Solicitor Virtanen, calmly advising a man whose neighbour’s prize-winning rooster was causing a noise nuisance. He nodded sympathetically, made notes, and suggested mediation, all while the chorus of his chosen first-week song, a bombastic U2 anthem, exploded on a loop in his head. The cognitive dissonance was staggering. He felt like a spy, living a cover life. He’d catch his reflection in the polished brass of the courthouse elevator doors and see a man in a sober grey suit, a briefcase full of other people’s problems clutched in his hand. But his eyes… his eyes held a frantic, secret sparkle. The spy knew his mission, and it had nothing to do with litigious poultry.

Telling his boss was the first, and highest, hurdle. Mr. Koskinen was a man carved from granite, a founding partner who viewed any time not spent billing as a personal affront. Aksel rehearsed his lines. A sick aunt. A sudden family crisis in the UK. A unique, once-in-a-lifetime opportunity to attend a specialist legal seminar on… something. They all sounded flimsy, transparent. He settled on a vague but hopefully impenetrable combination of all three.

He stood before Mr. Koskinen’s vast mahogany desk, a piece of furniture that had witnessed the crushing of far more formidable spirits than his. "Mr. Koskinen," he began, his voice a little tight. "A personal matter has arisen. In the United Kingdom. It requires my immediate and, ah, extended attention."

Koskinen looked up from a document, his glasses perched on the end of his nose. He peered at Aksel as if he were an interesting but ultimately flawed clause in a contract. "Extended?" the older man rumbled, the word echoing with financial implications.

"Potentially several weeks. It is… a family competition." The words tumbled out before he could stop them. A Freudian slip of spectacular proportions.

Koskinen’s eyebrows, formidable grey beasts, climbed his forehead. "A competition?"

"Of sorts," Aksel backpedalled, his cheeks burning. "An estate matter. Complicated. The British side of the family, you know. Eccentric." He was digging a hole. He needed to stop digging. He braced himself for the inevitable denial, the lecture on commitment and responsibility.

Instead, Koskinen leaned back in his leather chair, which sighed in protest. He steepled his fingers, a gesture Aksel had come to dread. "The United Kingdom, you say. My daughter is at Cambridge. Hates the food." He paused, a strange, almost wistful look in his eyes. "Very well, Virtanen. We are a small firm. This is an inconvenience. A significant inconvenience. But we are also a family. Of sorts." He waved a dismissive hand. "Go. Settle your eccentric British family competition. But I expect you to be available by email for emergencies. And don't lose."

Aksel stared. He had been so prepared for a fight, for a flat-out ‘no’, that the easy acceptance left him momentarily speechless. "Lose?" he repeated, confused.

"The competition," Koskinen said, already looking back down at his papers, the conversation clearly over. "Whatever it is. Don't lose. It reflects poorly on the firm."

Aksel backed out of the office in a daze. Don’t lose. The instruction, so absurd in its context, was oddly grounding. It was an order. And Aksel Virtanen was very, very good at following orders.

His flat was transformed. Legal pads were replaced by notebooks filled with frantic scrawls about stage presence and vocal warm-ups. The Helsinki legal code sat ignored while he studied YouTube videos of past X-Factor winners, dissecting their every move, their camera angles, their tearful backstories. He practiced in front of his bathroom mirror, trying to conjure a look of rock-and-roll angst, only to see the earnest, slightly worried face of a Finnish solicitor staring back. He tried a 'smoulder'. He looked constipated. He tried a 'power stance'. He looked like he was bracing for a strong wind. It was hopeless. He could sing, yes. The voice was there. But the rest of it, the 'X-factor' itself, felt like a foreign language he couldn't even begin to learn.

He packed his suitcase with the precision of a bomb disposal expert. Sensible shirts, a dark suit for any 'formal' events, and his best, most comfortable pair of black leather shoes. Then, hidden at the bottom, beneath a layer of woollen socks, was the evidence of his other life: a microphone-shaped stress ball, a throat spray he'd bought online, and a well-worn t-shirt of a Finnish metal band, a secret talisman. He stood in the middle of his living room, the suitcase at his feet, the flight confirmation glowing on his phone. The roar of the crowd was a distant, imaginary thunder. For the first time, the sheer, precipitous terror of what he was about to do washed over him, cold and absolute. He was Aksel Virtanen. He explained property tax law to pensioners. What in God’s name was he thinking? He was a fraud, a novelty act waiting to be discovered. A Finnish solicitor. They would laugh him off the stage. The silence in his apartment was suddenly deafening, a vast, empty space that the power of his voice could no longer fill. He picked up his suitcase. There was no turning back now. Mr. Koskinen had given him an order. Don't lose.

The flight to London was a study in contained anxiety. Aksel sat bolt upright, his hands clasped on his lap, declining all offers of food and drink. He stared out of the window at the endless expanse of clouds, a soft, white landscape that looked as unreal as his own future. London swirled beneath him, a vast, chaotic galaxy of lights, so different from the ordered geometry of Helsinki. A car was waiting for him, as promised in his information packet. A sleek, black car with tinted windows, driven by a man who grunted a greeting and communicated solely through the medium of aggressive lane changes. They swept through the rain-slicked streets, past landmarks Aksel had only ever seen in films. He felt like a character in one of them, a man on the run, a man with a secret identity.

The hotel was a whirlwind of noise and frantic energy. The lobby buzzed with people who were all younger, prettier, and more confident than he was. They had brightly coloured hair and clothes that seemed to be deliberately falling off. They laughed too loudly and hugged each other with a casual intimacy that Aksel, a man who considered a firm handshake a profound display of connection, found utterly bewildering. These were the other finalists. His competition. They looked like pop stars already. He felt like their lawyer.

A frazzled-looking woman with a clipboard and a headset surgically attached to her ear spotted him. "Aksel? Aksel Virtanen?" she yelled over the din. He nodded dumbly. "Great! You’re the last one. We were about to send out a search party. I'm Chloe, your contestant liaison. Basically, I'm your new best friend, mum, and drill sergeant all rolled into one. Got it? Good. Room 412. Press call in the lobby at 0800 tomorrow. Don't be late. And for God's sake, try and look a little less like you're here to audit us." She gave him a terrifyingly cheerful smile and was gone, swallowed by a gaggle of girls in matching sequined hotpants.

Room 412 was sterile and anonymous, but it was quiet. Blissfully quiet. Aksel dropped his suitcase and sat on the edge of the perfectly made bed. He looked at his reflection in the dark television screen. Chloe was right. He looked like he was here to read a will. He stood up, unbuttoned his sensible shirt, and walked over to the window. The view was of a brick wall. It was, in its own way, comforting. Familiar. He took a deep breath, the air tasting of air-conditioning and mild panic. He could do this. It was just a performance. A very, very, very public performance in front of millions of people who would be judging his every note, his every move, his every earnest, solicitor-like facial expression. His heart began its frantic drumming again. He reached into his briefcase, past the neatly filed travel documents, and his fingers closed around the cool metal of the microphone-shaped stress ball. He squeezed. It wasn't much, but it was a start.

The first day was a blur of scheduled chaos. The 8am press call was a terrifying ordeal. Flashing lights, shouted questions. He was shoved into a line-up with the other contestants, a bewilderingly diverse array of human beings. There was a girl band who communicated in high-pitched squeals, a gravel-voiced rocker old enough to be his father, a soulful teenager who looked like he might cry at any moment, and a duo of brothers who radiated an unnerving, vacant cheerfulness. Aksel stood amongst them, a block of Finnish granite in a sea of glitter. "The Finnish Solicitor!" a journalist yelled. "Sing us a bit of contract law!" Laughter rippled through the press pack. Aksel felt a hot flush of shame creep up his neck. He fixed his gaze on a point on the far wall and tried to project an aura of quiet dignity, hoping it wouldn't be mistaken for catatonia.

Then came the vocal coaching, the choreography sessions, the wardrobe fittings. Each was a fresh circle of hell. The vocal coach, a flamboyant man named Ricardo, praised his "instrument" but despaired at his "complete lack of emotional connection." He made Aksel lie on the floor and make primal screaming noises. Aksel, thinking of Mr. Koskinen, complied. The choreographer, a tiny, ferocious woman named Dani, moved with the sharp, angry energy of a wasp. She told him he had the "rhythmic grace of a filing cabinet" – the second time the furniture had been used as a pejorative against him in a week – and forced him to practice "walking with intent" for an hour. He felt less like a pop star in training and more like a malfunctioning robot being recalibrated.

Wardrobe was the deepest humiliation. A stylist named Kai, who wore sunglasses indoors and spoke in a language that was only tangentially related to English, held up various items of clothing against Aksel's chest with a look of profound despair. Ripped jeans. A leather jacket covered in more zips than a luggage factory. A see-through mesh vest. "Darling, your aura is just so… beige," Kai sighed, draping a feather boa around Aksel's neck. "We need to un-beige you. We need to find your inner sparkle." Aksel looked at himself in the three-way mirror. A man in a sensible suit, now adorned with a purple feather boa, looked back with the haunted eyes of a hostage. His inner sparkle, he suspected, had filed for a restraining order and moved to a different country.

He retreated to his room each night, exhausted and demoralised. The dream felt like it was curdling. This wasn't about the music, the voice. It was about the spectacle. It was about a personality he simply did not possess. He would phone his mother in Rovaniemi, who was thrilled but mostly concerned about whether he was eating enough vegetables. "They are giving me fruit platters, äiti," he'd say, staring at the untouched pineapple sweating in his room. "And just be yourself, Akseli," she'd advise warmly. "Everyone loves you." He didn't have the heart to tell her that 'himself' had been diagnosed as having the rhythmic grace of a filing cabinet.

It was during the third day of this bewildering bootcamp that something strange happened. They were rehearsing on the main stage for the first time, a vast, intimidating space. The empty arena seating rose up into the darkness like the skeletal remains of some great beast. Aksel was waiting in the wings, clutching his bottle of water, trying to ignore the nervous tremor in his hands. The brother duo, 'SparkleMotion' or something equally ghastly, were finishing their sound check. The melody was nauseatingly cheerful. And familiar. Painfully familiar. He found himself humming along, not just to the tune, but to the harmony. He knew when the key change was coming. He knew the precise moment the taller brother would gesture to the non-existent crowd.

He frowned, a headache beginning to prickle behind his eyes. How did he know this song? He loathed this kind of music. He wouldn’t have listened to it by choice. He shook his head, blaming the stress, the lack of sleep. Then the rocker, Dave, got up to sing. A classic '80s power ballad. Again, the same uncanny feeling. Aksel knew the arrangement. Not just the famous original, but *this* specific arrangement. The dramatic pause before the final chorus, the slightly altered guitar solo. It was like watching a film for the second time. He knew the lines before the actors said them.

A wave of dizziness washed over him. He leaned against a stack of equipment cases, the cold metal a shock against his skin. The stage lights seemed to burn with a new, aggressive intensity. The distant chatter of the crew, the hum of the electronics, it all merged into a disorienting roar. He closed his eyes. An image flashed in his mind, bright and fleeting as a camera flash. A spotlight. Blinding him. The roar of a real crowd, a deafening, physical wave of sound. The weight of a microphone in his hand. The feeling of a different suit on his shoulders, something sharper, more flamboyant. And a face. A woman's face in the front row, weeping with joy.

He gasped, his eyes flying open. His heart was hammering, not with anxiety now, but with a strange, frantic urgency, like a messenger trying to deliver a vital, forgotten message. Who was that woman? The memory, if that's what it was, was gone, leaving behind only a faint, ghostly echo of overwhelming emotion. Joy. Triumph. Relief. He felt a phantom ache in his throat, the ghost of a thousand songs sung at full volume. He looked out at the stage, at the giant 'X' logo suspended from the ceiling. He had the strangest feeling, a feeling so deep and certain it felt more like a memory than a thought. He had been here before. He had stood on that very spot. He had won this whole damn thing. The thought was insane. Utterly, certifiably insane. He was Aksel Virtanen, a solicitor from Finland. He had amnesia about winning the biggest talent show in Britain? It was the plot of a terrible, terrible movie. He shook his head again, harder this time, trying to dislodge the madness. He was just tired. He was stressed. He was a filing cabinet in a feather boa, and he was starting to lose his mind.

## Chapter 2

The madness, as he’d labelled it, did not recede. It clung to him like the damp London air, a persistent, chilling sensation that had nothing to do with the weather. He tried to construct a logical argument against his own senses, a closing statement to a jury of one. Exhibit A: sleep deprivation. Exhibit B: extreme stress. Exhibit C: an overactive imagination fuelled by a diet of lukewarm coffee and complimentary, vaguely menacing fruit platters. The conclusion was obvious: he was projecting his anxieties into a fantastical narrative of a forgotten past. It was a neat, tidy explanation. It was the kind of explanation Solicitor Virtanen would have offered a client. But it didn't feel true. The phantom ache in his throat, the ghostly echo of a thousand cheers… they felt more real than the flimsy hotel keycard in his pocket.

The next day’s rehearsals were an exercise in excruciating self-awareness. He watched the other acts with a forensic intensity, no longer seeing them as rivals but as potential clues. The way the soulful teenager, a kid named Leo, held the microphone, cradling it in both hands for the emotional climax of his song – Aksel’s own hands twitched in recognition. When Dani the choreographer screamed at the girl band to "Find your light! Feel the heat from F-spot, stage right!" Aksel’s eyes automatically flickered to the correct lighting rig, a piece of technical knowledge he had no earthly reason to possess. It was like living with a ghost, a far more talented and flamboyant ghost, who was constantly whispering stage directions in his ear.

His mission for the first live show, the bombastic U2 anthem, became a new form of torture. Ricardo, the vocal coach, was growing increasingly exasperated. "Aksel, darling, this is a song about surrender, about desperation, about finding something holy in the ruins! You are singing it like you're reading a grocery list. Milk. Eggs. Existential yearning." Ricardo fanned himself dramatically with a sheet of music. "There is no fire! I have seen more passion in a tax return."

Aksel tried. He really did. He thought about the crushing weight of his caseload, the grey Helsinki drizzle, the endless hum of the filing cabinet. He tried to pour that into the lyrics, to channel his quiet desperation. But it came out stilted, a performance of emotion rather than the thing itself. He was an advocate pleading a case he didn't fully believe in. His technique was flawless, his pitch perfect. But the song was hollow, a beautiful, empty vessel. He felt the ghost inside him, the rock god, slump in disappointment.

Frustrated, Ricardo stopped the backing track. "Okay. New plan. Forget Bono. Forget the X-Factor. Forget me." He sat down at the grand piano, his flamboyance momentarily replaced by a focused intensity. "Sing me something real. Something for you. The first thing that comes into your head. No, don't think," he commanded, as Aksel’s brow furrowed in concentration. "Sing." He played a simple, searching chord progression. It was melancholy and beautiful, and it resonated with something deep inside Aksel, striking a chord that wasn't on any sheet music.

Aksel closed his eyes. He let the piano wash over him, silencing the lawyer in his head. He didn't think about his mother, or Mr. Koskinen, or the humiliation of the feather boa. He thought of the image that had flashed in his mind. The spotlight. The roaring crowd. The weeping woman. And a melody surfaced, unbidden. The words followed, in English, as natural as breathing. It was a ballad, achingly sad and soaringly hopeful. He didn't know the song, and yet every word felt like his own.

His voice, when it came, was unrecognisable. All the meticulous control vanished, replaced by a raw, ragged vulnerability that cracked on the high notes with pure, unadulterated feeling. He sang of being lost and found, of a name he couldn't remember, of a face he was desperate to see again. He held the final note until his lungs burned with that familiar, glorious fire, his body vibrating with the force of it. When the note finally faded, he opened his eyes. The room was utterly silent. Ricardo was staring at him, his hands frozen over the piano keys, his mouth slightly agape. For the first time, the vocal coach was speechless.

"My God," Ricardo finally whispered, his voice hushed with awe. "Where in God's name did *that* come from?"

Aksel had no answer. He just shook his head, a profound and terrifying certainty dawning on him. That wasn't an act. That wasn't a performance. That was a memory.

The day of the first live show arrived like a death sentence. The hotel and the studio behind it had become a pressurised ecosystem of organised panic. People with headsets ran everywhere, their faces masks of strained urgency. The air was thick with the chemical fog of hairspray and the smell of nervous sweat. Aksel was taken by Kai to wardrobe and squeezed into an outfit that made the feather boa look like a business suit. It involved leather trousers that were so tight he feared for his future ability to have children, and a dark, glittery shirt unbuttoned to a point that felt professionally indecent. "We have found your sparkle, darling," Kai had declared, clapping his hands. "It was just buried under several layers of sensible cotton."

Backstage was a sensory assault. The bass from the warm-up act thudded through the floor, a physical, visceral pulse. In a brightly lit dressing room, he sat side-by-side with the other finalists, a row of condemned souls awaiting their turn. The brother duo were doing breathing exercises in unison. Dave the rocker was staring into space, mumbling his lyrics. Leo, the teenager, looked green. Aksel caught his own reflection in the mirror. The worried face of the Finnish solicitor was still there, but he was now trapped inside the costume of a B-list rock star. The cognitive dissonance was so strong it made him feel nauseous.

Chloe, his liaison, appeared at his shoulder, her usual frantic cheerfulness turned up to eleven. "Ten minutes, Aksel! You feel good? You look amazing! The quiet, mysterious type. The papers are loving it. 'The Helsinki Hummingbird!' Is that a thing? Doesn't matter! Just go out there and be brilliant. Break a leg! But not literally, the insurance paperwork is a nightmare." She squeezed his shoulder and was gone.

The Helsinki Hummingbird. It was even worse than the filing cabinet. He stood up, his legs feeling unsteady. A stagehand pointed him towards a dark corridor. "This way to the stage entrance, mate. Good luck." The corridor was cool and narrow, and at the end of it was a brilliant rectangle of light and a wall of sound. The muffled roar of the crowd. As he walked towards it, the smells hit him first. The scent of ozone from the electronics and a sweet, cloying odour he now recognised as the fog machine. The temperature changed, the cool air of the corridor giving way to the intense, dry heat of the stage lights. The floor beneath his feet changed from concrete to a slightly yielding sprung wood.

Every sensation was a jolt, a key turning in a lock he never knew existed. The ghost inside him wasn't whispering anymore. It was roaring. A final, vivid image flooded his mind, clearer than any before. He was standing on this exact spot. The heat on his face was the same. The roar was the same. He saw the woman in the front row, her face contorted with tears and pure, unadulterated pride. And this time, he saw her properly. He saw her grey-streaked blonde hair. He saw the familiar lines around her eyes. He knew that face. He knew it better than his own. It was his mother. But she had never been to London in her life.

"And now, all the way from Helsinki, the man they’re calling the Dark Horse of the competition! Singing U2’s ‘With or Without You,’ give it up for… Aksel Virtanen!"

A hand pushed him gently in the back. He stumbled forward, out of the darkness and into the blinding, absolute glare of the spotlights. The sound of thousands of people screaming hit him like a physical blow. He blinked, momentarily stunned, a rabbit in the headlights of an oncoming lorry. He found his mark, a simple cross of white tape on the black stage. It felt like the most familiar spot on Earth. The opening notes of the song began, that iconic, ethereal guitar riff filling the vast arena. He raised the microphone to his lips, his hand, to his profound surprise, perfectly steady. He looked down the barrel of the main camera, a single, unblinking red light. The world held its breath. And Aksel Virtanen opened his mouth to sing.

What came out was not the voice of Solicitor Aksel Virtanen. It was not the careful, technically proficient instrument he had honed in the sterile quiet of his Kallio apartment. This was another voice entirely. It was the voice of the man from the phantom memories, a voice weathered by a thousand smoky stages and steeped in a sorrow so profound it was almost beautiful. It bypassed his conscious mind completely. The lyrics, "I can't live with or without you," were no longer a poetic sentiment he was trying to convey; they were a raw, visceral truth torn from a place of deep, forgotten pain. He wasn't performing a song; he was testifying. His body, the same body that looked like it was bracing for a strong wind in rehearsal, moved with a fluid, unconscious grace. A hand lifted, not in a practiced gesture, but as if to ward off a memory. His eyes, fixed on the red light of the camera, weren't vacant but filled with an ancient, howling grief that spoke directly to every person watching. He was a vessel, and something vast and powerful was pouring through him.

When the final, haunting note faded into the cavernous space of the arena, a strange, absolute silence fell. It was not the polite quiet of an unimpressed audience; it was a breathless, collective hush, the sound of thousands of people forgetting to breathe. For a split second, Aksel felt the 'other man' recede, leaving him blinking in the glare, his heart thundering with a confusing mix of exhilaration and terror. Then, the silence shattered. The roar that erupted was a physical force, a tidal wave of sound that washed over him, so much louder and more real than the ghost of applause in his memory. People were on their feet. The weeping woman from his vision was gone, replaced by a sea of illuminated faces, all turned towards him, their expressions a mixture of shock and rapture.

He stood, dazed, as the host jogged onto the stage, clapping him on the back. The judges were standing, a rare tribute. "Aksel," said the famously acerbic one, his usual sneer replaced by a look of grudging astonishment. "I don't know who you are, or where you have been hiding, but that was not a competition performance. That was the performance of an artist. It was raw, it was real, and it was, frankly, breathtaking." The other judges chimed in with a torrent of superlatives—'mesmerising', 'revelatory', 'a triumph'—that seemed to be about someone else entirely. Aksel just nodded, mumbling "Kiitos. Thank you," his mind a maelstrom of confusion. He felt like he had just woken from a fever dream to find he’d won an Olympic medal in a sport he’d never played.

The chaos backstage was even more intense. Contestants he’d barely spoken to clapped his shoulder, their eyes wide with a new, wary respect. Chloe, his liaison, was practically vibrating with excitement, screaming "You were incredible! Incredible!" into her headset. He was hurried through corridors, his tight leather trousers chafing, his mind blessedly blank. He wanted order. He wanted his green blotter and his parallel pens. He wanted the monotonous, reassuring C-sharp of the filing cabinet. Instead, he was adrift in a sea of noise and praise he felt he hadn't earned. He finally escaped to the sterile anonymity of his hotel room, shutting the door on the circus and leaning against it, his breath coming in ragged gasps. Who was that on stage? Who was that man?

An hour later, the show was replaying on television. He sat on the edge of the bed, his hands clenched, and forced himself to watch. He saw a man who looked like him, wearing a ridiculous shirt, standing on a stage. But the man's eyes were different. The way he held himself, the way his throat strained on the high notes, the sheer, unvarnished agony in his expression—it was like watching a stranger. A stranger who had somehow stolen his body. He felt a profound sense of dislocation, a vertigo of the soul. He wasn't the Helsinki Hummingbird. He was a man haunted by a better singer. He reached for his phone, his fingers dialling a familiar number before he had even consciously decided to.

"Akseli! My star!" His mother's voice was bright and full of pride. She had clearly been watching. "You were wonderful! So handsome! Though that shirt was a little… open, wasn't it? But your voice! It was like an angel singing."

"Äiti," he began, his own voice sounding thin and strange to his ears. "I need to ask you something. It’s a strange question."

"Anything, rakas."

He took a breath. "Have I ever… been to the UK before? For a long time? Maybe a few years ago?" He braced himself, not knowing what he wanted her to say.

There was a pause on the line, just long enough to make his stomach clench. "To the UK? No, of course not. You went to London once for a university trip, for a few days, remember? You said it was too crowded. Why do you ask?" Her voice was perfectly normal, full of gentle, maternal confusion. There was no flicker of deception, no hint of a secret. The vision of her in the crowd, weeping with pride, had to be a fantasy. A symptom of his cracking psyche.

"No reason," he lied, a wave of disappointment and relief washing over him. "Just… feeling a little confused. It's a lot to take in."

"Just be yourself, Akseli," she said again, her simple, loving mantra. "That's all you need to do."

He ended the call feeling more lost than before. If his mother didn't know anything, then the memories weren't real. They were hallucinations. He was just a solicitor having a very public, glitter-dusted breakdown. He turned to his laptop, the one tool he trusted to bring order to chaos. He opened a search engine, his fingers hovering over the keyboard. What could he possibly search for? *Finnish man has delusion of being a rock star? Symptoms of a bifurcated personality?* He typed, slowly and deliberately, "Aksel Virtanen singer". The first few pages were all about the X-Factor. 'Finnish Solicitor Stuns Judges.' 'The Dark Horse from Helsinki.' He scrolled past them, digging deeper. He added terms like 'London,' 'gig,' 'unsigned.' Nothing. He was a ghost on the internet until a month ago. On a whim, he tried a different search. He typed in the lyrics he had sung in the rehearsal room for Ricardo, the ones that had appeared from nowhere. "A name I can't remember, a face I need to see."

The search engine returned millions of results for sentimental poetry, but one link on the fourth page caught his eye. It was a post on an old, defunct music forum from three years ago. The thread was titled "Who was that Finnish guy at The Blue Posts?" A user named 'GtrHero82' had written: *Saw an open mic night there last week. Most of it was dross, but this Finnish guy got up at the end. Didn't even give his name. Just sat down with a guitar and sang this one song that blew the roof off. Something about a name he couldn't remember. Never seen anything like it. Anyone know who he was?* The thread died after two more posts, both from people who hadn't been there.

His blood ran cold. The Blue Posts. A pub. An open mic night. Three years ago. It was a breadcrumb, a tiny, tangible piece of evidence that he was not entirely insane. He searched for the pub, found its location in Soho. He looked at the street view, the digital image of the pub's exterior. The red brick felt familiar. A new search. "Finnish singer disappears London." More scrolling. He found a short article in a local London paper’s online archive, dated almost exactly three years ago. The headline was small, insignificant. 'Concern for Missing Tourist.' He clicked. The story was brief. A Finnish man in his late twenties, in London on a personal trip, had been reported missing by his hotel. His name was Ari Virtanen. He had checked in, but then vanished, leaving his luggage and passport in his room. The police were appealing for information. The article was accompanied by a grainy, low-quality photo. It was a man with dark hair, looking away from the camera, his features obscured by shadow. But there was something about the set of his shoulders, the shape of his head. He looked like Aksel. He looked exactly like Aksel. Ari. Not Aksel. But Virtanen. A strange, choked sound escaped his lips. The article mentioned one final detail. The date Ari Virtanen was reported missing. It was the night after the open mic performance mentioned in the forum. And it was the night before a terrible, multi-car pile-up on the M4 motorway, an accident that had left one unidentified man with a severe head injury and total amnesia.

The cursor blinked on the screen. A single, rhythmic pulse of white on black in the silent hotel room. Blink. Blink. Blink. It was a digital heartbeat, steady and unforgiving, counting out the seconds of a life that Aksel was no longer sure was his. *Ari Virtanen.* The name echoed in the hollow space behind his own. It felt both alien and intimately familiar, like a word on the tip of his tongue. He scrolled back to the grainy photograph. A man with his shoulders, his hair, his essence, caught in a moment of unguarded existence before vanishing into thin air. A man who sang a song of loss before becoming lost himself.

The lawyer in him, the part of his brain that thrived on order and logical deduction, scrambled to build a defense against the impossible. It was a coincidence. A tragic, statistically improbable, but ultimately explainable coincidence. There were other Virtanens in Finland. There were other dark-haired men. The song lyrics on the forum could be a fabrication, a simple case of two people having a similar creative thought. The car crash on the M4 motorway was a public tragedy, a piece of information his subconscious could have absorbed from a forgotten news report and woven into this elaborate stress-induced fantasy. He was Aksel. His life was a meticulously documented testament to that fact. He had tax records. A degree certificate. A mother who would know, who *would have known*, if her son had disappeared and been replaced by a stranger.

But the ghost inside him, the singer with the fiery ache in his lungs, laughed at the lawyer's closing arguments. The ghost knew the worn grain of the bar at The Blue Posts. The ghost remembered the specific chill of a London back alley. The ghost felt the phantom weight of a guitar case in a hand that now only ever held a briefcase. The ghost knew, with a certainty that defied logic and law, that the man in the grainy photo was him. And the unidentified man with the head injury and amnesia… a man who would need a new identity, a new life, a new, meticulously ordered existence to replace the one that had been shattered… the conclusion was inescapable. He wasn't a man haunted by a singer. He was a singer haunted by a solicitor. The persona of Aksel Virtanen, the sensible shoes, the aligned pens, the C-sharp of the filing cabinet—it wasn't his sanctuary. It was his cage. A carefully constructed, quiet, beige cage built around a void.

He closed the laptop, the sudden darkness feeling like a mercy. Who was he, then? If he was Ari, the man who vanished, then who had he been for the past three years? The details of his life as Aksel, which had once been his bedrock, now seemed flimsy and suspect. He remembered graduating from law school, but the memories were muted, like watching a film. He remembered starting at Virtanen & Koskinen, but the memory lacked the sharp sting of first-day nerves. He remembered his mother's pride, but it felt like a story he’d been told, not a moment he had lived. It was all a narrative, a backstory provided to him by… by who? Doctors? The state? How does a person with no past get a past? His mind, trained to follow a paper trail, reeled at the lack of one. There was no 'before'. His conscious memory began abruptly, three years ago, with a dull headache and a profound sense of dislocation that he'd always attributed to a bad flu.

The next day’s schedule, slipped under his door during the night, felt like a message from a different universe. 10:00 - Choreography. 12:00 - Media training. 14:00 - Wardrobe consultation for Week 2 theme ('Movie Night'). He was living a double life in more ways than he could have imagined. Not just a solicitor pretending to be a rock star, but an amnesiac pretending to be a solicitor, now pretending to be a rock star. The absurdity was dizzying.

He had to get out. He had to get to that pub. The need was a physical craving, overriding the demands of the show, the fear of Kai and his sparkly fabrics, the thought of Mr. Koskinen's disapproval. He waited until nine-thirty, then called Chloe's number. He pitched his voice low, adding a slight rasp. "Chloe, it's Aksel. I'm sorry. I have a terrible migraine. The lights yesterday… I think it was too much. I can’t… I can't rehearse today."

"A migraine! Oh, you poor thing!" Chloe’s voice was a cocktail of genuine sympathy and producer-level calculation. "Is it a good TV migraine? Like, tragically pale and brooding? Or a blotchy, puffy-eyed one? We can work with either. The viewers love a bit of vulnerability."

"It's the… can't-see-or-think-and-need-total-darkness kind," Aksel said, closing his eyes and pressing the heel of his hand to his forehead for effect, even though he was alone.

"Right. The non-telegenic kind. Got it. Okay, stay in your room, lots of water. I'll cancel your sessions. But Aksel," her voice turned serious, "you HAVE to be well for Saturday. The public fell in love with you. We need you."

"I will be," he promised, the lie tasting like ash. "I just need today."

He waited a full hour after the call, a tense, coiled silence in his room. Then, he put on the most anonymous clothes he owned—a dark grey jumper, plain trousers, and a black beanie hat he'd bought at Helsinki airport. He looked in the mirror. He no longer saw a solicitor or a pop star. He saw a spy. A man on a mission to uncover his own life. He slipped out of the room and took the service stairs, his heart pounding a frantic rhythm against his ribs. He bypassed the buzzing lobby and exited through a side door into the drizzling London morning. For the first time in days, he felt the cold, damp air on his face, unmediated by air-conditioning or stage lights. It felt real.

The tube ride to Soho was a journey through a dreamscape. He was surrounded by people, a river of humanity flowing around him, yet he felt profoundly alone, an island of untold secrets. He emerged at Leicester Square, the familiar-yet-unfamiliar chaos of the area hitting him with force. He didn't need the map on his phone. His feet knew the way. He turned down a side street, then another, the grand facades giving way to narrower lanes, the smell of rain, stale beer, and exhaust fumes filling the air. He saw it at the end of the street. The Blue Posts. Its red brick was dark with rain, its windows glowing with a warm, welcoming light. It looked exactly as it had in the street view image, yet infinitely more real. His stomach twisted. He was standing at the edge of his own past.

Taking a deep, shaky breath, he pushed open the heavy wooden door. The bell above it gave a dull jingle. The pub was quiet, it being mid-morning. A couple of old men nursed pints at a corner table. The air was thick with the scent of wood polish and beer. Behind the bar, a man in his fifties with a craggy face and tired eyes was wiping down the counter. He looked up as Aksel entered, his expression professionally blank.

Aksel walked to the bar, his sensible leather shoes making no sound on the worn floorboards. Every detail felt like a clue. The scuffed brass footrail. The slight stickiness of the wooden bar top. The way the light from the window caught the dust motes dancing in the air. He had been here. He knew it with a certainty that vibrated in his bones. "Hello," he said, his voice quiet.

"What can I get you, mate?" the bartender asked, his tone flat.

"Just… a water. For now." He needed to keep a clear head. The bartender placed a glass in front of him. Aksel’s hands were trembling slightly as he reached into his pocket and pulled out his phone. He opened the photo of himself, the one from the X-Factor press release—the clean-shaven, haunted-looking man in the sober suit. "I have a strange question," Aksel said, pushing the phone across the bar. "Have you ever seen this man before?"

The bartender glanced at the phone, then up at Aksel's face, hidden partially by the beanie. He squinted. "Is this a wind-up?"

"No. Please. It's important."

The man leaned closer, peering at the photo, then back at Aksel. He looked at him properly now, his gaze sharp and discerning. His eyes widened slightly in recognition, but it was a confused recognition, as if he were looking at a misremembered photograph. "Well, you look like him," he said slowly, rubbing his chin. "But he was… different. Younger, maybe. More fire in his eyes. Less… haunted." He tapped the counter. "Yeah, I remember him. Finnish lad. Came in a few times, about three years back. Didn't say much, just sat over there," he nodded towards a small, shadowy table in the corner, "with a guitar. Then one night, he got up for the open mic. Never seen anything like it. Shut the whole place up."

Aksel’s heart felt like it was going to beat its way out of his chest. It was real. "Do you remember his name?" he asked, his voice barely a whisper.

The bartender frowned, thinking. "Something… Scandinavian. Ar-… Arn-… Ari. That was it. Ari." The name landed in the quiet pub like a thunderclap. Ari. He said it. A stranger, a witness, had confirmed the name of the ghost.

"Ari," Aksel repeated, the single word a universe of questions.

"That's the one," the bartender said, looking at him with renewed curiosity. "He sang one song, then just walked out. Never saw him again. We all wondered what happened to him. So, you a brother? A relative?"
