Words like *'farmatsevtika'*—pharmaceuticals, likely a euphemism for illegal drugs. And next to one specific entry, a single, chilling annotation: *'Chelovek'.* Man. Human.

A wave of nausea washed over him. The firm wasn't just a front; it was an active participant in gun running, drug smuggling, and human trafficking. And he, Aksel Virtanen, had been their diligent, unknowing paper-pusher. The final piece of the puzzle slotted into place. Ari hadn't just been a singer who saw something he shouldn't have. He had been part of it. The ledger wasn't just observations; it was his own record. He had tried to get out, and for that, they had tried to erase him. Koskinen hadn't just given him a new life out of some twisted sense of mercy. He had repurposed a valuable asset. Who better to handle the legal minutiae of a criminal empire than a brilliant lawyer with no memory of the crimes he was helping to conceal? The order 'Don't lose' now rang in his ears with its true, terrifying clarity. It meant: Stay famous. Stay visible. Stay under our control. Because you know everything, even if you don't remember it. And we can't afford to let you disappear again.

## Chapter 6

The discovery did not break him. It forged him. The man who woke on the morning of the second live show was a fusion of two selves, a creature of chilling duality. The solicitor's meticulous, analytical mind was now the operating system for the singer’s wounded, furious heart. He was Ari’s anger filtered through Aksel’s logic. The knowledge of his own complicity, the fact that Ari had not been an innocent bystander but a bookkeeper for monsters, did not fill him with guilt. There was no time for that. It was simply data. It explained the desperation in Ari’s flight, the terror that had propelled him to create the failsafe in Paddington Station. He hadn’t just been running from punishment; he had been running from himself.

The pre-show preparations unfolded around him like a silent film. He sat in the makeup chair, a woman dusting powder onto his face to dull the shine under the hot lights, and saw not his own reflection, but the cool, detached face of an operative preparing for infiltration. He was sheathed in the costume Kai had chosen for him—simple black jeans, a dark grey Henley shirt. It was stark, minimalist. “We are going for tortured poet, darling,” Kai had declared. “The music demands it.” Aksel had simply nodded. The tortured poet was an excellent cover for the vengeful ghost.

As he waited in the wings, the thumping bass of the opening group number vibrating through the floor, the other contestants buzzed around him, a flock of nervous, glittering birds. Leo, the teenager, wished him good luck, his eyes wide and sincere. The brother duo gave him a vacant, double-thumbed salute. They were children playing a game, and he was a soldier heading to the front line. He felt an immense, sorrowful distance from all of them. His competition was not on this stage. His competition was a man in Helsinki, a man who built empires on the bones of the people whose names were scrawled in Ari's notebook.

When his name was called, he walked onto the stage with a calm, deliberate tread. The roar of the crowd was a distant, irrelevant ocean of sound. He ignored the judges. He ignored the host. He walked to the lone stool at the centre of the stage, the acoustic guitar feeling like a familiar weapon in his hands. The house lights went down, and a single, stark white spotlight pinned him to the stage, creating an island of light in a sea of darkness. This was his territory. He looked down the barrel of the main camera, the red light a single, unblinking eye connecting him directly to millions of television screens. He knew Koskinen would be one of them. He took a breath, not of nerves, but of resolve. Then, he began to play.

The performance was an act of war disguised as a folk song. The fury he had shown Ricardo in rehearsal was now honed to a razor's edge. He sang the opening lines, *'Hello darkness, my old friend,'* and it was a greeting to the man who had tried to bury him in it. His voice was low, intimate, a conspiratorial whisper that drew the entire arena, the entire country, into his confidence. He was sharing a secret, and the tension was unbearable. He imbued every line with a second, hidden meaning. *'People talking without speaking'* was the lie of his own life, the pleasantries with his colleagues, the phone calls with his mother. *'People hearing without listening'* was the audience, consuming his pain as entertainment, blind to the truth screaming from behind the lyrics.

When he reached the crescendo, his voice didn't soar with emotion; it hardened with accusation. *'And the sign flashed out its warning / In the words that it was forming.'* He struck the guitar with a percussive, angry force, his eyes burning into the camera lens, a direct challenge to the man he knew was watching. He was the sign. He was the warning. He finished the song with the final, whispered lyric, letting the last chord decay into absolute, profound silence. He didn't smile. He didn't bow. He simply stared into the camera, his message delivered, holding the entire nation in a moment of stunned, uncomfortable quiet.

The applause, when it came, was hesitant at first, then thunderous, but it was different from the week before. It was not the sound of pure adulation, but of shock and awe. He stood, slinging the guitar behind his back, and faced the judges' table. They looked unsettled. The usually acerbic judge was frowning, his pen tapping against the desk. “Aksel,” he began, choosing his words carefully. “Artistically, that was… a masterpiece. It was compelling. But it was also one of the most uncomfortable, chilling things I have ever seen on this stage. It felt less like a song and more like… a confession. Or an accusation.” The other judges echoed the sentiment, praising his bravery and artistry but all noting the cold, unnerving fury at the heart of the performance. They didn't understand it, but they felt it. The message had been received, even if it hadn't been decoded.

Backstage was a blur of hurried congratulations and confused glances. Chloe looked at him, her usual cheerfulness tempered with something like fear. "That was… intense, Aksel. Are you okay?" she asked, her voice low. "I'm fine," he replied, his voice flat. "It's just a song." He shrugged off her attempts to guide him to the press room, mumbling an excuse about needing a moment. He found an empty corridor behind a stack of flight cases, the distant roar of the show a muffled pulse. He pulled out his phone. The screen was dark. He stood in the shadows, waiting. He knew it wouldn't be long.

Less than five minutes later, the phone vibrated in his hand. The screen lit up with a number he didn't recognise, but he knew instantly who it was. The country code was +358. Finland. He let it ring three times, a small act of defiance, before answering. He said nothing. "Aksel," the voice on the other end was unmistakable. It was Mr. Koskinen. The tone was not angry. It was calm, measured, and dripping with disappointment, the voice of a chairman addressing an underperforming board member. "A bold artistic choice this evening. Very… dramatic."

"I thought it was appropriate for the theme," Aksel replied, his own voice equally devoid of emotion.

There was a dry chuckle on the other end of the line. "Indeed. You have always been a thorough worker. But this particular project seems to be generating some… unnecessary noise. It could be viewed as a distraction from your primary duties." The subtext was as clear as a legal summons. You are making a scene. Stop it.

"My only duty right now is to this competition," Aksel said, testing the boundary.

"Of course," Koskinen’s voice was smooth as silk. "And we are all so proud of your success. Your mother, especially. I spoke with her just earlier this evening. She is so thrilled, but so worried about the pressure you are under. Such a fragile constitution she has. It would be a terrible shame if anything were to cause her any… undue stress." The threat was delivered with surgical precision, a knife wrapped in velvet. *We know where she is. We can reach her.*

The cold fury in Aksel’s chest solidified into a block of pure, hard ice. He thought of his mother's terrified voice on the phone. "I understand," Aksel said, his knuckles white as he gripped the phone. "There will be no more… unnecessary noise."

"I'm glad we're on the same page," Koskinen said, the satisfaction in his voice palpable. "You are a valuable asset, Aksel. Don't forget that. Keep winning. Make us proud." The line went dead.

Aksel slowly lowered the phone. The war was no longer cold. It was declared. Koskinen had confirmed the stakes, laid his cards on the table, and placed his mother squarely on the betting felt. He couldn't fight him from the stage anymore. He couldn't send messages. Any act of defiance would now have immediate and terrible consequences for the only person he had in the world. He was trapped. He had to keep singing, keep smiling, keep playing the part of Aksel Virtanen, the grateful finalist, all while knowing his handler held a gun to his mother’s head. He looked down the dark corridor, back towards the noise and the light of the show. He had to go back out there, back into the cage. But as he stepped out of the shadows, a new, desperate plan began to form in his mind. He couldn't fight Koskinen. But maybe, just maybe, Ari could.

He stepped back out of the shadows into the garish, artificial world of backstage television. The results of the public vote were coming in, and the air was thick with the cheap perfume of manufactured tension. Chloe spotted him and rushed over, her face a mask of professional relief. "Aksel! There you are! You’re through! Landslide vote, apparently. You’re through to next week!" She grabbed his arm, her grip surprisingly strong, and pulled him towards the jubilant, hugging mass of contestants who had survived the night. He forced a smile, a rictus grin that felt like it might crack his face. He allowed himself to be hugged by the weeping girl-band member whose name he couldn't remember. He was playing the part. He was Aksel Virtanen, the emotional, grateful finalist. Inside, Ari was making a battle plan.

As the chaos began to subside, a figure detached itself from the shadows near the dressing rooms. It was Ricardo. The vocal coach approached him not with the boisterous congratulations of the others, but with a quiet, searching intensity. He waited until they were in a secluded corner, away from the whooping and the popping of champagne corks. "That was not a song you sang tonight, Aksel," Ricardo said, his voice low and serious, all flamboyance stripped away. "That was a declaration. A message to someone. I don’t know who, and I don’t want to know. But I know a man who is singing for his life when I see one." Aksel’s blood ran cold, but his face remained a mask of weary artistry. "It’s a powerful song," he repeated his earlier deflection.

Ricardo shook his head, a gesture of profound sadness. "Don’t insult my intelligence. I have coached divas who would sell their own mothers for a high note and rock stars who have burned down hotel rooms. I know performance. What you are doing… this is something else entirely." He looked around, ensuring they were not being overheard. "I am not part of this… machine. Not really. I am just a musician they pay to fix voices. If you are in trouble, the kind of trouble that goes beyond winning a singing competition, you need an ally. Someone who isn't holding a clipboard or a camera." He slipped a small, crisp business card into Aksel’s hand. "This is my private number. My real number. If the darkness ever gets too loud, call it." Before Aksel could respond, Ricardo gave him a small, sad nod and melted back into the celebratory din, leaving Aksel with the small, rectangular piece of card feeling like a lifeline and a trap all at once.

Sleep was an impossibility. The hotel room was no longer a sanctuary; it was a command centre. He locked the door, wedged a chair under the handle, and laid out the contents of the backpack on the floor like a general assessing his arsenal. The photograph of Koskinen. The map. The dead burner phone. And the notebook. He ignored Ricardo’s card for now. An alliance with the vocal coach was a desperate, last resort. First, he had to exhaust his own intelligence. He had to become Ari again, the man who had compiled this ledger of secrets. He opened the notebook, his solicitor’s mind scanning the pages not just for crimes, but for weaknesses. For anomalies. For a name that didn’t fit the pattern of Russian thugs and corrupt Finnish businessmen.

He found it on the third-to-last page, almost an afterthought. It was an English name: 'Julian Croft'. Next to it was a London phone number and a single, cryptic word: 'Insurance'. The handwriting was hurried, more so than the rest, as if it had been jotted down in a moment of extreme duress. Insurance. It wasn't a financial term. In the world that these documents described, a world of smuggled weapons and trafficked human beings, 'insurance' meant leverage. It meant a contingency plan. Julian Croft was not a friend. He was a professional, someone Ari had either hired or made a deal with, a fail-safe in case the worst happened. This was the person you called when you needed a ghost to reappear, when you needed leverage against men like Koskinen. This was the first move Ari had planned, a move Aksel had only just discovered.

He needed a phone, one that couldn't be traced back to the show, to Aksel Virtanen. He couldn't use the burner from the bag without a charger, and he couldn't risk buying one. His plan was simple and direct. The next morning, feigning a walk to clear his head after his 'emotional' performance, he found a cleaner working in a quiet corridor on a different floor. He cornered the man, a young immigrant with wary eyes. Aksel didn’t try to explain. He simply pulled out a thick wad of cash from the emergency fund he’d brought from Helsinki, peeling off five hundred pounds. "I need a phone," Aksel said, his voice low and urgent. "An old one you don't use. And the charger. Untraceable. No questions." The cleaner’s eyes widened at the sight of the money, a sum that was likely more than a month's wages. He hesitated for only a second, then nodded, disappearing into a supply closet and emerging moments later with a scuffed, older-model smartphone and a coiled charging cable. The exchange was made in silence. The cleaner took the money and vanished. Aksel now had his weapon.

Back in the suffocating privacy of his room, he plugged the phone in, watching the screen flicker to life. He swapped the SIM card for a new, unregistered one he’d also bought from the cleaner for another hundred pounds. He was now a ghost on the network. He waited until the dead of night, when the hotel was finally still. He took the phone into the bathroom, closed the door, and turned on the extractor fan, the low hum a flimsy shield against any listening devices. His heart hammered against his ribs. This was it. The point of no return. He was no longer Aksel Virtanen, the confused finalist. He was Ari, making the call he should have made three years ago. His fingers, surprisingly steady, dialled the number from the notebook. It rang twice, a sharp, British tone. Then a voice answered, a man’s voice, crisp and educated, with an undercurrent of irritation. "Yes?"

Aksel took a breath, the stale, air-conditioned air of the bathroom filling his lungs. He had to choose his words carefully. He was activating a protocol he didn't fully understand. "I’m calling about an insurance policy," he said, the phrase feeling alien and melodramatic on his tongue. There was a pause on the other end, a silence so profound Aksel could hear the faint static on the line. The voice, when it came back, was sharper, colder. "State the policy holder's name." This was the moment. The claiming of his own ghost. He closed his eyes, the face of Aksel Virtanen receding, the face of the man in the grainy news report coming into focus. He opened them again. "Ari," he said, his own voice sounding strange and new to him, the name a key turning in the lock of his own soul. "Ari Virtanen."

The silence that followed the name was not empty. It was dense and heavy, filled with the static of three years of quiet, the unspoken questions, the assumed death. For a full five seconds, the only sound was the hum of the bathroom fan and Aksel’s own blood roaring in his ears. When the voice on the other end returned, it was transformed. The bored irritation was gone, replaced by a low, dangerous focus, the sound of a predator that has just caught a scent it thought long vanished from the earth. "That's a name I haven't heard in a long time. A name belonging to a dead man. Who is this?"

Aksel’s mind raced. This was a test. A security question from a life he didn't remember living. He needed a key, a password. He squeezed his eyes shut, trying to force a memory, but only the cold hard data from the notebook was there. Data. That was it. Ari was a bookkeeper. He would have used numbers. “Check the transaction log for February the third, three years ago,” Aksel said, his voice a low, steady command. “An outgoing payment to a holding company, ‘JC Risk Consulting’. The amount was twelve thousand four hundred and fifty pounds sterling. An uneven number, to avoid automated financial flags.” It was a detail he had noticed, a piece of professional caution that felt like Ari’s signature.

Another silence, this one shorter, sharper. Aksel could hear the faint, distant click of a keyboard. “The account was closed a week after you disappeared,” the voice, Julian Croft’s voice, stated. It wasn’t a question. It was a confirmation. “I was paid to hold a data package and release it to a predetermined list of journalistic and law enforcement contacts in the event of your confirmed death, or six months after your unconfirmed disappearance. I was preparing to do the latter when I received a visit.” Aksel held his breath. “From whom?” he asked, though he already knew the answer.

“A very persuasive gentleman from a very respectable Helsinki law firm. He provided evidence—convincing evidence, I might add—that you had not disappeared, but had suffered a severe psychotic break. That you were an unstable addict who had concocted a paranoid fantasy and that releasing the data would not avenge your death but would actively endanger you in the specialist private clinic where you were being treated. The story held together. My retainer had been paid, but my release fee had not. I placed the insurance policy on indefinite hold.” A pause. “It seems I was misled.” The tone was dry, utterly devoid of apology. It was the voice of a man admitting to a bad investment, not a moral failure.

Aksel’s stomach churned. Koskinen’s genius was not just in his criminality, but in his meticulous administration of the lies that surrounded it. He had not only hidden the body; he had discredited the soul. "That data package," Aksel said, his voice tight. "I need you to release it. Now." Croft laughed, a short, sharp, humourless bark. "Absolutely not. The terms of our agreement are null and void. You are not dead. You are, in fact, incredibly, inconveniently, and very publicly alive. Do you have any idea what would happen if I released that data now? Koskinen's organization isn't some historical problem; it's active. And it knows where you are. Releasing that data wouldn't just be my death sentence; it would be yours. They wouldn't need to hide you this time."

The cold logic of the statement was undeniable. He couldn't win with a simple email bomb. They had to be smarter. "Then what do you propose?" Aksel asked. "The package contains the original data," Croft said. "Unredacted. The names of his suppliers in the Russian military, the buyers in the UK, the real identities of the people on his trafficking routes. It's not just evidence; it's a weapon. And it's useless to me on a hard drive. I want to meet. You and me. We discuss a new arrangement. A new fee. And a new strategy that doesn’t involve us both ending up as footnotes in a boating accident report."

A rendezvous. It was exactly what Aksel had anticipated and feared. A meeting would mean leaving the gilded cage. "Where and when?" he asked, his mind already working, plotting, constructing the next necessary lie for his keepers. "Tomorrow. Two p.m. The Turbine Hall at the Tate Modern. It’s big, it’s public, there are cameras everywhere, and there are a hundred ways in and out. Wear something distinctive, but not flashy. A red scarf. Don't be late. And come alone. If I see a camera crew, a producer, or anyone who even looks like they know what a key light is, I’m gone." The line went dead before Aksel could reply.

The next morning, he put his plan into motion. The theme for the coming week was 'British Icons'. It was perfect. He cornered Mark in the canteen, feigning a new crisis of artistic integrity. "Mark, I need your help," he began, his face a mask of tortured creativity. "This week, British Icons. It's a trap. Everyone will do the obvious. Queen, Elton John, The Beatles. I want to do something different. Something that speaks to the real, gritty London. I want to sing a song by The Kinks. 'Waterloo Sunset'." Mark looked intrigued. "It’s a classic," he mused. "Bit low-key, but the public loves you being sad."

"Exactly," Aksel pressed. "But I have never seen a Waterloo sunset. I've only read the words. It feels fraudulent. To sing it with real conviction, I need to experience it. I need to go to Waterloo Bridge. I need to see the city from that perspective. The dirty old river. The Houses of Parliament." He was weaving a narrative he knew the producer couldn't resist. It was a perfect sequel to the Paddington Station story. The Moody Finn Seeks Poetic Inspiration. Mark's eyes lit up. "I love it. The journey of the artist. It's gold." He agreed immediately, with one condition. "Same deal as before. One hour. One camera. But this time, I want a bit more. I want you to talk to the camera. Tell them what you’re feeling. Give us the internal monologue."

It was a complication, but a manageable one. An hour on Waterloo Bridge was more than enough time. The Tate Modern was just a short walk down the South Bank. He could perform his monologue for the camera, then claim he needed a moment alone to 'absorb the atmosphere', giving him a window to slip away, meet Croft, and return. The risk was monumental. He would be watched by the camera, and potentially by Koskinen’s people. But it was the only path forward.

The next afternoon, he stood on Waterloo Bridge, the grey London sky pressing down on him. The wind was sharp, whipping a cheap red scarf he'd bought that morning around his neck. The two-man camera crew stood twenty yards away, filming him as he stared out at the iconic view. He played his part perfectly. He delivered a hushed, thoughtful monologue about art, loneliness, and the beauty of a city he was pretending to discover for the first time. He spoke of Ray Davies and the poetry of the everyday. It was a masterful performance. Then, he turned to the cameraman. "Thank you," he said, his voice quiet. "I need… I need a few minutes. Just to be here. Alone. No camera. Please." The cameraman, used to the eccentricities of 'talent', grumbled but acquiesced, lowering his camera. This was his window. He gave them a grateful, solitary nod and started walking east along the South Bank, towards the looming chimney of the Tate Modern. Every step was a gamble. He felt a thousand invisible eyes on his back. The tourist crowds were a sea he had to navigate, a perfect camouflage. He pulled his beanie down, hunched his shoulders, and melted into the river of people, the red scarf a single, bright flag of hope and of danger.

The walk along the South Bank was the longest ten minutes of his life. The cheerful, bustling chaos of the tourist thoroughfare was a surreal counterpoint to the icy dread coiling in his gut. Every person who glanced at his red scarf was a potential assassin. Every laugh from a passing group felt like a mockery of his predicament. He kept his head down, his shoulders hunched, trying to shrink into himself, to become just another anonymous figure in the crowd. The towering chimney of the Tate Modern grew closer with every step, a grim industrial finger pointing at a sky the colour of old pewter. It was a monument to a forgotten age of power, a fitting venue for a meeting with a ghost from his own forgotten past.

He pushed through the heavy glass doors and was immediately swallowed by the immensity of the Turbine Hall. The scale of the place was humbling and terrifying, a vast concrete canyon where sound echoed and human figures were reduced to scurrying ants. It was, as Croft had surmised, the perfect place for an anonymous meeting. He could be watched from a hundred different angles, yet lost in a moment. Following the man's instructions, he walked the length of the hall, his footsteps echoing faintly, before turning and finding a place to lean against a concrete pillar near the back, partially obscured from the main entrance. He crossed his arms, feigning a look of artistic contemplation, and waited, his eyes scanning the crowd, his senses screaming.

He didn’t see Croft approach. One moment he was alone, the next a man was standing beside him, examining a nearby installation with mild, academic interest. He was in his late forties, dressed in a dark, impeccably tailored tweed jacket over a simple grey jumper. His face was unremarkable, the kind of blandly handsome English face that could belong to a banker, a history professor, or a high-end assassin. It was a face designed to be forgotten. He didn't look at Aksel. "The red scarf is a bit theatrical, don't you think, Ari?" Julian Croft said, his voice the same crisp, calm tone from the phone. "I'd have picked you out without it. You still have the same walk. Like you're expecting the ground to give way."

"You said distinctive," Aksel replied, his own voice low, his gaze fixed on a family taking a selfie a hundred feet away. He felt a phantom memory of this man, not a specific event, but a feeling—the professional chill of a necessary but distasteful transaction. "You've aged," Croft observed, finally turning to look at him, his eyes a pale, intelligent grey. They held no warmth, only a constant, unnerving assessment. "But the amnesia has been good for you. It's cleared out the panic. You were always too emotional. It was a liability."

"The panic is still there," Aksel said, the admission a calculated risk. "It's just better organised." A flicker of something that might have been respect crossed Croft’s face. "Good. Then you'll understand when I tell you that your plan to release my data package is amateurish, suicidal, and frankly, an insult to the fee I was paid to acquire it." He spoke with the detached air of a consultant critiquing a flawed business plan. "You can't fight an organisation like Koskinen's with a data dump. He has government contacts, kill teams, and more money than God. The moment those files go public, we are both dead, and the story will be buried under a mountain of disinformation about a deranged X-Factor contestant and his conspiracy-theorist accomplice."

"Then what was the point of the insurance?" Aksel shot back, his frustration turning to a low, simmering anger. "The point," Croft said, "was leverage. A loaded gun to be used in a negotiation, not a bomb to blow up the entire building. The situation has changed. You are no longer a ghost to be avenged; you are a high-profile asset. And that, Ari, makes you uniquely dangerous to them, and uniquely useful to me." He paused, letting the implication hang in the cavernous space. "Koskinen made a mistake. He should have left you dead. Instead, he made you famous. He put his missing bookkeeper on the biggest stage in the country. We are going to use that stage to burn his entire empire to the ground."

The audacity of the plan was breathtaking. Aksel felt a surge of wild, reckless hope. "How?" Croft began to walk slowly, forcing Aksel to fall into step beside him, two anonymous figures moving through the modern art. "We don't go after the king. We go after his London castle. Koskinen's entire UK operation—the logistics, the money laundering, the distribution—is run by one man. A former MI6 officer, dishonorably discharged. Name's Alistair Finch. He's ruthlessly efficient, fiercely loyal, and pathologically discreet. He is Koskinen’s eyes and ears in this city. We're going to make him break cover."

He explained the strategy with the same cool precision he might use to describe a corporate takeover. Aksel’s next performance on the X-Factor would be the bait. The theme was 'British Icons'. He would choose a song, and within that song, he would embed a message. Not a public cry for help, but a private signal aimed directly at Finch. A code. A name from Ari's ledger, a date, a fragment of information that only Finch would understand, a signal that Ari's memory was back and that the London operation was compromised. "Finch's protocol for a breach of this magnitude will be simple: eliminate the source," Croft concluded, his voice a chilling whisper. "He will come for you. He won't send a street-level thug; he's a professional. He'll do it himself. And when he makes his move, my people will be there to intercept him. We take Finch, we acquire his network, and we hand the entire, gift-wrapped package to the one branch of British intelligence that Koskinen hasn't bought. They get a major international criminal. I get a substantial reward and a new client in the intelligence services. And you," he glanced at Aksel, "you get your life back. Or what's left of it."

It was a plan of insane risk and beautiful, ruthless logic. It used Aksel as both bait and hunter, leveraging his fame as the ultimate trap. "What's your price?" Aksel asked, knowing the answer would be steep. "My fee for this new venture is two hundred thousand pounds, wired to an account I will provide," Croft stated without hesitation. "And I want the original notebook. All of your research. It's my insurance against you. Once Finch is in our custody, I get the ledger, and you get a copy of the original data package and a new passport. You can disappear for good this time. Or you can stay and be a pop star. Frankly, I don't care."

He stopped near the exit. "Do we have a deal, Ari?" Aksel looked at the man's impassive face. He was making a deal with the devil to hunt a demon, but he had no other choice. "We have a deal," he said. Croft nodded, a curt, business-like gesture. "Good. The first piece of bait is the name of the boat Finch used for his first major weapons shipment into the UK. It was called 'The Ondine'. A sentimental choice; it was his mother's name. The theme is British Icons. I'm sure you and your artistic soul can find a way to work it in. I'll be in touch with the account details." Croft turned and blended into the stream of people leaving the gallery, vanishing as quickly as he had appeared. Aksel was left alone, his heart pounding, the name 'Ondine' echoing in his mind. He glanced at his watch. He had been gone for twenty-seven minutes. He had to get back to the bridge. He pulled the red scarf tighter around his neck and ran.

He hit the Waterloo Bridge at a half-run, a stitch burning in his side, his lungs raw from the cold air. The camera crew was packing up, the light fading fast. The main cameraman, a burly man named Steve, looked up from his tripod, his expression a mixture of boredom and irritation. He saw Aksel approaching, the red scarf a bright slash of colour against the grey twilight, and his expression softened into professional resignation. The mad Finnish artist was back from his spirit quest.

"Cutting it a bit fine, mate," Steve grunted, gesturing towards the sky, which was bruising into a deep violet. "Lost the sun. Hope you found your 'dirty old river'."

Aksel didn't slow his pace until he was right beside them, leaning against the parapet, forcing deep, calming breaths. He arranged his features into a mask of weary revelation, his eyes distant as he gazed at the river. "Yes," he breathed, the word fogging in the air. "It's… more than I expected. The weight of all the history. It's overwhelming." The lie came easily, a well-rehearsed line from a play he was perfecting. He had learned that the language of artistic angst was a universal passport, granting him access and pardoning his eccentricities. The crew bought it completely. They filmed a final, moody shot of him staring pensively at the distant lights of Parliament before packing him into the car and returning him to the glittering cage of the hotel. He had made it back. The first part of the plan was complete.

The next morning, he walked into the song selection meeting with a singular purpose. Mark and Chloe were waiting, armed with a whiteboard covered in predictable choices: Queen, The Beatles, Adele. Mark looked up, a predatory gleam in his eye. "Aksel! The Poet of Waterloo Bridge! The dailies look fantastic. The network loves it. So, what's it to be? 'Bohemian Rhapsody'? You’ve got the range. 'Someone Like You'? Guaranteed waterworks from the judges." Aksel ignored the whiteboard. He walked to the head of the table and placed a single sheet of paper down. On it were the printed lyrics to Kate Bush's "Hounds of Love".

A baffled silence fell over the room. Chloe squinted at the paper. "Hounds of Love?" she repeated, as if the words themselves were in a foreign language. Mark laughed, a short, sharp bark. "Aksel, this isn't an art school dissertation. It's Saturday night television. It's a brilliant track, but it's weird. It’s all yelping and weird drum machines. People will be changing the channel." "No, they won't," Aksel said, his voice quiet but absolutely firm. He met Mark's cynical gaze. "They won't because it’s the most honest song I could possibly sing. Read the lyrics. It's a song about being hunted by fear, about running in the dark. It’s about needing someone to save you. Last week, you told me I was compelling because I was uncomfortable, because I was real. This is more real than anything else on that list. Let me do this, and I promise you, people will not be able to look away." He was selling them his own terror as a unique selling proposition, and he could see from the slow, calculating look on Mark's face that the producer was starting to see the commercial potential in his pain. "Alright, Virtanen," Mark finally sighed, running a hand through his thinning hair. "You want to go full-on art-house weirdo, be my guest. But if the viewing figures drop, it's on your head."

His session with Ricardo was a different ordeal entirely. The vocal coach looked at the sheet music, and a deep, weary sadness filled his eyes. He didn't mock the choice. He didn't question its commercial viability. He simply sat down at the piano and began to play the song's anxious, driving chord progression. After Aksel had sung it through once, his voice capturing the frantic, pleading desperation of the lyrics, Ricardo stopped. He turned on the piano stool, his face grim. "The hounds are real, aren't they, Aksel?" he asked softly. It wasn't a question that demanded an answer. It was a statement of fact. "Whoever you are running from, they are getting closer."

Aksel said nothing, his silence a confession. Ricardo nodded slowly, a deep understanding passing between them. He was no longer just a coach; he was a silent witness. "The arrangement," Ricardo said, his voice dropping to a conspiratorial whisper, his eyes flicking towards the door. "It needs to be… emptier. More frantic. In the middle section, after the chorus, the rhythm breaks down. The original has layered vocals, strange sounds. We will strip it back. We will leave… space. A silence where you can hear a heartbeat. A space for a breath. Or a word." He looked at Aksel, his meaning perfectly, terrifyingly clear. He didn't know the plan, but he knew Aksel needed a weapon, and he was helping him to forge it. He was giving him the silence where he could place the hook.

That night, alone in his room, a text message arrived on the burner phone. It contained only a string of numbers—a Swiss bank account—and a single word: *'Now'*. The transfer was the next logistical nightmare. He couldn’t use his Helsinki bank account; the amount would trigger alarms, and Koskinen would see it instantly. He had to use the cash he had left. The next day, feigning a need for "specialist Finnish throat lozenges that you can only get from one specific shop", he convinced a bewildered production assistant to take him to a part of London known for its discreet, no-questions-asked currency exchanges. Over the course of two hours, he visited six different establishments, breaking the two hundred thousand pounds into smaller, untraceable wire transfers from different bogus company names, a trick he remembered from a long-forgotten fraud case he had studied. As the final transfer was confirmed, he felt a profound, irreversible shift. He was no longer just an informant. He was now a co-conspirator, financially bound to Julian Croft. He had paid the devil his due.

The day of the show was a study in controlled terror. Every smile, every pre-show interview, every interaction was a performance of a lifetime. He was acutely aware of the chain of events he was about to set in motion. His life, his mother's life, and the lives of Croft's unseen team depended on his ability to embed a single, obscure word into a pop song convincingly. As he stood in the wings, waiting for his name to be called, he could feel his heart hammering against his ribs, a frantic drumbeat that matched the song's intro. He was the bait. The stage was the trap. And the hook was a four-syllable word whispered into the silence.

The host yelled his name, and he walked out into the blinding lights. The crowd's roar was a physical wave, but he barely heard it. His focus was absolute, narrowed down to the red light on the camera and the task ahead. The frantic, synthesized beat of "Hounds of Love" began. He gripped the microphone, his knuckles white. He sang the opening verse, his voice a raw, desperate plea. He was no longer acting. He was living the lyrics. He was the fox, and the hounds were closing in. He poured all his fear, all his rage, all his desperate hope into the performance. Then came the middle eight. As Ricardo had designed, the music stripped away, leaving only a sparse, pulsing heartbeat of a bass drum and a ghostly synthesizer pad. The silence he had been given. He sang the line, "I'll be two steps on the water," his voice cracking with emotion. Then, in the gaping void of the music, he leaned into the microphone, his eyes closed, and whispered the name, a ghostly, half-remembered secret breathed into the ears of millions. *"Ondine."* He held the moment, then launched into the final, desperate chorus, screaming for someone to take his shoes and throw them in the lake, to make him want to live. It was done. The hook was in the water. All he could do now was wait for the monster to bite.

The final note of the song, a desperate, fading cry, was swallowed by the cavernous arena. For a full three seconds, the silence he had created on stage spread outwards, infecting the entire audience. It was a vacuum, a void filled only with the echo of a whispered name no one had consciously registered but everyone had felt. Then, as if a spell had been broken, the arena erupted. It wasn't just applause; it was a roar of shock, sympathy, and a kind of fearful respect. People were on their feet, not just in celebration, but as if compelled to rise by the sheer, unvarnished force of the performance.

Aksel stood panting, his body trembling with a violent adrenaline crash. The host jogged onto the stage, giving him a wide berth as if he were a piece of unstable ordinance. He clapped Aksel tentatively on the shoulder. "Wow," the host said, his voice unusually subdued, speaking to the camera. "I think I speak for everyone when I say we have just witnessed something incredibly special and incredibly raw. Judges?" The judges looked poleaxed. The acerbic one, who had been so unnerved the week before, simply shook his head, his face a mixture of awe and concern. "Aksel," he said, his voice low. "That was… an exorcism. I have no other word for it. It was terrifying, and it was brilliant. I genuinely hope you're alright." Aksel simply nodded, unable to form words, the mask of the broken artist his only shield. He had fired the shot. Now he was just waiting to hear the bullet hit its target.

The pandemonium backstage was a surreal, dizzying vortex. He was mobbed, hugged, and congratulated by people whose faces swam before his eyes. Chloe was weeping openly, dabbing her eyes with a tissue. "That was the most honest thing I've ever seen on television," she sobbed, clutching his arm. "You're not just a singer, Aksel, you're a goddamn national treasure!" Through the blur, he saw Ricardo standing apart from the crowd, near the entrance to the dressing rooms. The vocal coach didn't approach. He simply met Aksel's gaze across the chaos and gave a single, almost imperceptible nod. It was a confirmation. *Message received. I am your witness.* It was a small comfort, a single steady point in a world that had just tilted into a lethal, high-stakes game.

Miles away, in a minimalist penthouse apartment overlooking the dark, swirling ribbon of the Thames, Alistair Finch did not applaud. He sat perfectly still in a leather Eames chair, a glass of colourless, expensive gin resting on the table beside him. The television was a large, silent rectangle on the wall; he had been listening to the audio feed through a high-fidelity, encrypted channel on his laptop, monitoring the asset. The room was cold, an exercise in controlled taste—grey walls, steel fixtures, no photographs, no clutter. It was the habitat of a man who left no trace. He had listened to the performance with the detached interest of a technician checking a machine's output. Then he had heard the word. *Ondine.* It was not a mumble. It was not a breath. It was a whisper, as precise and deliberate as a stiletto blade sliding between two ribs.

Finch did not flinch. His expression did not change. But a profound, absolute stillness descended upon him. He calmly reached forward and terminated the audio feed. For a full minute, he sat in complete silence, the only sound the faint hum of the city far below. He was processing the new data. The amnesiac bookkeeper had his memory back. The insurance policy he and Koskinen had thought dormant was now active. The quiet, controllable asset had just become a live threat in the most public arena imaginable. He picked up his gin, not to drink, but to feel the cold condensation on his fingertips. Protocol was clear. A breach of this nature required immediate, decisive containment. He rose from his chair, walked to his laptop, and typed a single, encrypted message to a subordinate: *'Initiate surveillance package Nightingale. Full spectrum. I want to know when he breathes.'* Then he opened a separate, highly secure file on his desktop. It was a blueprint of the X-Factor studio and the contestants' hotel. He began to plan the hunt.

Aksel finally made it back to the sanctuary of his hotel room, his body aching with a tension so profound it felt like a physical illness. The feigned exhaustion and emotional fragility had taken their toll. He locked the door and slid the chain across, leaning his forehead against the cool wood, his breath coming in ragged gasps. He had done it. He had walked into the lion's den and tweaked its nose. Now the waiting began. He sat on the edge of the bed in the darkness, the burner phone clutched in his hand, a talisman in a world of ghosts. The minutes stretched into an hour. Every creak of the building, every distant siren, every muffled footstep in the corridor was the sound of his own death arriving. He was a man in a cell, waiting for the executioner's footsteps.

Just after 2 a.m., the burner phone vibrated, a sudden, violent buzz against his palm that made him jolt. A text message glowed on the screen. It was from Croft. It contained only five words: *'The water is red. Stand by.'* A cold dread, colder and deeper than anything he had felt before, washed over him. It wasn't just 'circling'. The water was red. The monster was bleeding, or it was coming to make him bleed. It meant Finch was not just aware; he was active. He was moving. The hunt had officially begun. Aksel stared at the words, the glowing green text a promise of imminent violence. He was no longer waiting for a killer. The killer was now waiting for him.

The next few days were a masterclass in psychological torture. Aksel had to navigate the relentlessly cheerful, utterly mundane schedule of the show, all while knowing a professional killer was dissecting his life, looking for a point of entry. He attended press calls, smiling blandly and giving vague, artistic answers about his "emotional process." He sat in wardrobe fittings, nodding as Kai draped him in different fabrics, his mind a million miles away, calculating angles of attack and escape routes from the hotel. He felt Finch's unseen eyes on him everywhere. The CCTV camera in the hotel lift felt like a personal intrusion. The over-friendly new concierge who seemed to know his schedule felt like a spy. He was living in a panopticon, and the chief warden was a man who wanted him dead.

He was in a vocal session with Ricardo, mechanically running scales, when the second message from Croft arrived. He had hidden the burner phone in his jacket pocket, and the vibration was a secret jolt against his ribs. He excused himself, claiming a coughing fit, and retreated to the bathroom. The message was longer this time, a set of precise, cold instructions. *'Finch has you under full surveillance. He will not risk an attack at the hotel or studio. Too many witnesses. He will wait for you to be isolated. We will provide that isolation. Tomorrow, you will inform your producer that you need to visit a specific location for artistic inspiration for this week's theme, 'Love & Heartbreak'. St Dunstan-in-the-East. It's a ruined church garden in the city. Finch's surveillance will flag it as a perfect kill zone. It is. But the trap will not be for you. Be at the entrance at 3 p.m. sharp. Wear the red scarf. My team will be in position. Follow their instructions to the letter. Do not deviate.'* Aksel stared at his own pale, terrified face in the mirror. They were flushing the target. And he was the worm on the hook.

## Chapter 9

The lie was becoming a second language, a fluent, effortless tongue he now spoke more comfortably than his native Finnish. He stood before Mark and Chloe the next morning, his face a carefully constructed canvas of artistic turmoil. The theme of ‘Love & Heartbreak’ was, he explained with a quiet, soulful gravity, profoundly challenging for him. It was too broad. He needed a specific anchor, a physical metaphor for a love that was ruined but whose beauty endured. He had been researching, he told them, and had discovered a place in the heart of the city: St Dunstan-in-the-East, a church bombed in the Blitz, its hollowed-out shell now a public garden. A place where destruction and nature had intertwined to create something new, something beautiful and sad. It was, he whispered, the perfect visual representation of a broken heart.

Mark, who now saw Aksel not as a contestant but as a walking, breathing human-interest story guaranteed to spike ratings, practically leapt at the idea. “The Ruined Church! Aksel, it’s genius! It’s poetic, it’s tragic, it’s visual! The juxtaposition of ancient stone and modern skyscrapers! It’s a metaphor for your entire journey!” The producer was already storyboarding the segment in his head, his eyes alight with the fire of manufactured drama. The permission was granted instantly, enthusiastically. The same parameters were set: one hour, one camera crew, one mission to capture the soul of the Moody Finn.

The journey into the City of London was a slow, deliberate procession into the mouth of the trap. Aksel sat in the back of the black car, the red scarf a coarse, vibrant weight around his neck. He watched the streets of London slide by, every passing vehicle a potential tail, every reflection in a shop window a possible observer. He knew, with absolute certainty, that he was being watched by two separate teams: the X-Factor crew in the car behind him, and the unseen, far more dangerous eyes of Alistair Finch’s surveillance. He was the focal point of two entirely different narratives—one of art and celebrity, the other of espionage and death. He had to perform for both audiences simultaneously, his outward expression one of thoughtful melancholy, his inner world a screaming vortex of tactical analysis.

St Dunstan-in-the-East was a quiet shock, a secret garden hidden in the belly of the beast. He stepped through a stone archway and the roar of the city fell away, replaced by the gentle rustle of leaves and the coo of pigeons. Gothic stone arches, blackened by time and fire, stood open to the sky, their empty windows framing the gleaming glass towers of the financial district. Ivy clung to the walls like a green shroud. It was beautiful, serene, and utterly menacing. The perfect place for an ambush. He gave a nod to the camera crew, who began setting up near the entrance, and started his slow, contemplative walk, the red scarf a bloody flag against the ancient grey stone.

He performed his part, tracing the lines of a fallen pillar with his fingers, staring up at the empty sky through a ruined window frame. All the while, his senses were stretched to a breaking point, cataloguing every other person in the garden. A pair of office workers eating their lunch on a bench. A young couple whispering by a fountain. A man in a high-vis jacket tending to a flowerbed near the far wall. The man in the high-vis jacket. Aksel’s eyes flickered towards him, then away. The man was methodically pulling weeds, his movements economical and precise. He seemed to belong. Aksel meandered along a path that brought him closer. As he passed, the gardener looked up, his face bland and forgettable. “Afternoon,” the man grunted, then gestured with his trowel towards a narrow, arching pathway obscured by overgrown shrubs. “Mind using the main path, sir? Just treating the flagstones down there. Slippery.” The instruction was casual, perfectly pitched. Aksel gave a small nod of acknowledgement and changed his direction, moving away from the open central lawn and down the main stone path, towards the more secluded eastern end of the garden. He was being guided.

He found a stone bench nestled within a crumbling alcove, partially hidden from the main entrance but with a clear view of the path ahead. He sat, the cold stone seeping through his jeans. This was it. The designated spot. He pulled a small notebook and a pen from his jacket—props for his performance—and pretended to write, his hand trembling almost imperceptibly. The garden had emptied slightly as the lunchtime visitors returned to their offices. The quiet was deeper now, more absolute. He could hear the frantic beat of his own heart. He waited. For Croft’s team. For Finch. He didn’t know which would appear first.

He saw the man approaching from the corner of his eye. He did not look like a killer. He looked like a solicitor. Dressed in a dark, well-cut suit that didn’t quite belong in a garden, he was in his fifties, with thinning grey hair and a calm, academic face. He walked with a quiet confidence, his polished shoes making no sound on the stone path. He stopped a few feet from Aksel’s bench and pretended to admire a patch of wallflowers, his hands clasped behind his back. It was Alistair Finch. The man was radiating a lethal, bureaucratic calm. “They said you were a solicitor, Mr. Virtanen,” Finch said, his voice a pleasant, cultured baritone that carried easily in the quiet air. He didn’t look at Aksel. “I find that hard to believe. Solicitors are cautious. They file paperwork. They don’t send engraved invitations to their own executions.”

Aksel’s blood turned to ice, but he kept his head bent over his notebook. “I was just looking for some inspiration,” he replied, his voice a low tremor. “A song about love and heartbreak.” Finch chuckled, a dry, rustling sound. “Ondine. A tragic water nymph who cursed her unfaithful lover to a waking death. A rather obscure and aggressive choice of heartbreak, wouldn't you say? Especially for a man who is supposed to remember nothing.” He finally turned, and his eyes, a pale, washed-out blue, were devoid of all emotion. They were the eyes of a man looking at a problem to be solved, not a person to be killed. “Koskinen is sentimental. He saw an opportunity to keep a useful asset on the books. I advised against it. Loose ends should be tied, not repurposed. It seems my initial assessment was correct.” He took a step closer. From the inside pocket of his suit jacket, he produced a slim object that looked like a fountain pen. He clicked the top. A needle, less than an inch long and glistening with a clear fluid, emerged from the tip with a faint, metallic *snick*. “Fentanyl, mixed with a potassium chloride solution. Quick. Quiet. It will look like a simple, tragic cardiac event. The tortured artist, overwhelmed by the pressures of fame. The media will write your eulogy for you.”

Aksel’s body was frozen, his mind screaming. He looked past Finch, desperately searching for a sign of Croft’s team. The garden was empty. The trap had failed. He was alone with his executioner. Finch took another step, raising the pen. “A shame,” he said conversationally. “You have a remarkable voice.”

It was then that the gardener in the high-vis jacket, who had been silently working his way along the far wall, stood up. At the same moment, the young couple who had been whispering by the fountain also rose, their romantic facade evaporating. They moved in a silent, coordinated triangle, their movements fluid and economical. Finch sensed the shift in the atmosphere an instant before it happened. He started to turn, his professional calm finally cracking, the needle swinging towards the new threats. He was too late. The gardener was impossibly fast. He closed the distance in two silent strides, his arm lashing out not with a trowel, but with a thin, black garrote wire. The wire looped over Finch’s head, snapping tight around his throat. The woman from the couple stepped in, her hand striking Finch’s wrist with brutal precision, sending the needle pen clattering to the flagstones. The other man kicked the back of Finch’s knees, buckling his legs. The entire takedown was over in less than three seconds. It was utterly silent, brutally efficient, and horrifying to watch.

Finch didn’t even have time to struggle. He was bundled backwards, half-dragged, half-carried, through a low, previously unnoticed door in the ancient stone wall, a door that had been hidden behind a thick curtain of ivy. The door closed, and they were gone. Aksel was left sitting on the bench, his heart trying to hammer its way out of his chest, the silent scream still lodged in his throat. A moment later, Julian Croft stepped out from behind a thick yew tree, looking as calm and unruffled as if he had just been admiring the foliage. He walked over and picked up the needle pen with a handkerchief, examining it with detached curiosity before pocketing it. “Excellent. Punctual and efficient. I do hate a fuss.” He looked at Aksel’s ashen face. “Breathe, Ari. The hard part is over. For now.” Croft handed him the burner phone. “Go back to your camera crew. Tell them the muse has provided her inspiration. You have a television show to win.” He gave a thin, bloodless smile. “After all, you’re a national treasure now.” Then he, too, turned and walked away, disappearing down a side path, leaving Aksel alone in the sudden, deafening silence of the ruined garden.

## Chapter 10

It took a full minute for Aksel’s legs to obey him. He sat on the cold stone bench, the silence of the garden a roaring in his ears, his gaze fixed on the ivy-covered wall that had swallowed three men and a brutal act of violence whole. His mind, the solicitor’s mind, was trying to process the event, to file it under a known category, but there was none. He had just witnessed a man being professionally disappeared, seconds after that same man had been poised to murder him with a fountain pen. His body was a chaos of post-adrenaline tremors, his hands shaking so violently he had to clench them into fists to still them. He was alive. The thought was not triumphant; it was a staggering, bewildering fact.

He forced himself to his feet, his muscles stiff and uncooperative. He had to walk back to the camera crew. He had to be Aksel Virtanen, the pensive artist, not Ari Virtanen, the man who had just served as human bait. He took a deep, shuddering breath and started the slow walk back towards the entrance. He focused on the mechanics of it: left foot, right foot. He schooled his features into a mask of weary introspection, hoping it would be mistaken for artistic immersion. Steve, the cameraman, was packing away a lens case, his expression one of pure, unadulterated boredom. He looked up as Aksel approached.

"Alright, mate? Got what you needed?" Steve asked, his voice a gravelly monotone. "You look like you've seen a ghost." The casual accuracy of the remark sent a jolt of icy fear through Aksel, but he managed a slow, tired nod. "Something like that," he murmured, his voice hoarse. "It’s a powerful place. I think… I think I have the song now." The cameraman grunted, accepting the explanation without question. To him, Aksel was just another piece of high-maintenance talent, prone to fits of dramatic melancholy. The profound, life-altering violence that had just occurred ten yards away was utterly invisible to him, a different dimension of reality. The sheer banality of the crew’s conversation as they packed him into the car was a form of psychological torture, a dissonant soundtrack playing over the silent scream in his mind.

Back in the anonymous safety of his hotel room, the facade crumbled. He locked the door and leaned against it, his legs finally giving way as he slid to the floor. The image of the garrote wire, of Finch’s eyes widening in a brief, final moment of professional surprise, was burned onto the inside of his eyelids. He had been complicit. He had led a man to a trap where he was ambushed and abducted. It didn't matter that the man was a killer who had been about to end his life; the cold, transactional nature of the event left a stain on him. He was no longer just a victim. He was a player in their savage game, his hands stained with the same ink. The burner phone vibrated in his pocket. He fumbled for it, his fingers clumsy and numb. It was a message from Croft. *Asset secured. Awaiting debrief. You performed well. Lie low.* The message was as cold and efficient as the takedown itself. He had performed well. He was the star of the show, in more ways than one.

The next day, he walked into his session with Ricardo like a man returning from a war. The haunted, anxious quality that had defined him was gone, replaced by a hollow-eyed stillness, the quiet of a man who has looked into the abyss and seen it blink first. He placed a new sheet of music on the piano. "Waterloo Sunset". Ricardo looked at the title, then up at Aksel's face, his gaze sharp and deeply knowing. He didn't ask about the ruined church. He didn’t need to. He could see the ruins in Aksel's eyes. "Ah," Ricardo said softly, a world of understanding in the single syllable. "The song you lied about. A song about watching the world from a safe distance, feeling beautifully sad. A survivor’s song." He turned to the piano and began to play, the familiar, gentle melody filling the room. He didn’t coach. He accompanied. He followed Aksel’s lead as he sang, his voice no longer raw with anger or fear, but imbued with a profound, weary melancholy, the sound of a man who had paid an unbearable price for the view from the bridge.

While Aksel sang of sunsets, Julian Croft was at work. Finch, a professional conditioned by a lifetime of knowing when a game was lost, was proving to be a wealth of information. Another message arrived on the burner phone that evening. *Finch is talking. His network is being dismantled as we speak. Koskinen is blind in London, and he knows it. He's panicking. He will view you not as a threat, but as his only remaining link to his UK operation. He will try to contact you. Do not answer any calls from unknown Finnish numbers. The final phase is approaching. The grand final.* The message was a shot of pure adrenaline. Koskinen was cornered. A cornered animal was the most dangerous kind. Aksel knew, with a dreadful certainty, that Koskinen would not try to reach him through a sterile, deniable phone call. He would use a weapon that was far more intimate.

The call came the next evening. It came not to the burner phone, but to the official X-Factor mobile that Chloe had given him. The screen lit up with the name he both longed for and dreaded: ‘Äiti’. His mother. His hand trembled as he answered, a cold knot of fear tightening in his stomach. Her voice, when it came, was thin and strained, a pale imitation of its usual warmth. "Akseli? Rakas, it’s me." He could hear the forced brightness, the terror humming just beneath the surface. He knew instantly that she was not alone. Koskinen was in the room with her. He was standing over her, his presence a poison in the air between them. "Äiti, what is it? Is everything alright?" he asked, playing his part, his voice full of a love and concern that was agonizingly real.

"Everything is fine, wonderful," she said, her voice unnaturally high. "Mr. Koskinen is here. He’s been so kind. He’s worried about you, Akseli. We both are. This… this silly show. It’s too much for you. You sound so tired. We think you should come home." It was a plea and a command, her words a script written by the man holding her hostage. "Mr. Koskinen has arranged everything. He can have a car waiting for you at the airport. You can just leave. Forget all this nonsense. Come home to us. Please, Akseli. I miss you so much." A small, choked sob escaped her, a sound so genuine and full of pain that it felt like a physical blow.

He closed his eyes, the image of his mother’s terrified face filling his mind. This was the final test. Koskinen was using his last, most valuable weapon. To agree would be to walk directly into his captor’s arms, to invalidate everything he had sacrificed, to render Finch's capture meaningless. To refuse would be to tighten the screw on his mother, to leave her in the hands of a desperate, cornered monster. He thought of Croft's plan, of the final, decisive trap that needed to be set. There was only one path forward. He had to sever the connection. He had to abandon his mother to save her.

"I can't, Äiti," he said, his voice quiet, steady, and devastatingly calm. The words tasted like glass in his mouth. "I have to finish what I started. This is important. But I will see you soon. I promise." He poured every ounce of love and reassurance he could muster into that final promise. Before she could reply, before Koskinen could force another word from her, he ended the call. He sat in the silence of his room, the phone dead in his hand, the finality of his choice settling upon him like a shroud. He had refused the ransom. He had just dared the devil to do his worst. The board was set for the final move, and it would all play out on the stage of the X-Factor grand final.

The silence that followed was more profound than any he had ever known. It was the silence of a bridge burned, a lifeline severed. He sat motionless, the dead phone a cold, useless weight in his hand. He had just condemned his mother to the company of her tormentor, armed only with the desperate, flimsy hope that his refusal would be seen as a sign of strength, a warning that he was no longer controllable. He felt the two halves of himself at war: Aksel, the son, was screaming in a silent agony of guilt and terror; Ari, the strategist, was coldly calculating the odds, marking the sacrifice as a necessary, brutal move in a game with no other rules.

Sleep was a distant country he could no longer visit. He spent the night staring at the ceiling, the city lights painting shifting patterns on the walls. He was a ghost in his own life, haunted by a past he couldn’t fully remember and a future he might not live to see. The victory over Finch felt hollow, a tactical skirmish in a war whose emotional cost was proving unbearable. Koskinen had escalated the conflict from the professional to the personal, and in doing so, had shown Aksel the true path to victory. To defeat Koskinen, he couldn't just expose the criminal; he had to destroy the man.

At dawn, he picked up the burner phone. His message to Croft was terse, devoid of the panic raging inside him. *'Contact made. Mother is hostage. He wants me to walk into the trap. I refused. Your move.'*

Croft’s reply came within minutes, as cool and immediate as a surgeon's diagnosis. *'Predictable escalation. He's using his final leverage. This is not a weakness. It's an opportunity. A cornered predator is reckless. We will use his desperation to force a rescue operation for your mother. He won't trust anyone else. He will have to expose his own operational command in Finland. The Grand Final is in three days. That is our stage.'*

The final week of the X-Factor was a hallucinatory blur. Aksel was one of two finalists, pitted against Leo, the soulful teenager whose journey had been one of innocent, wide-eyed wonder. The contrast was a narrative made in heaven for the producers. The Dark Horse versus the Nation's Sweetheart. The media frenzy was relentless. Aksel was trailed everywhere, his "tortured artist" persona now cemented in the public consciousness. He gave interviews in a near-catatonic state of emotional exhaustion, his vague, monosyllabic answers interpreted as profound depth rather than the soul-crushing terror they truly were.

He had one final meeting with Croft, a fleeting, two-minute encounter in the echoing stairwell of a multi-story car park. Croft looked at him, his pale grey eyes taking in Aksel's hollowed-out expression. "You are at your breaking point," he stated, not with sympathy, but with analytical approval. "Good. You will be believable." He handed Aksel a tiny, flesh-coloured earpiece, no bigger than a pea. "This is a one-way communication device. My team will be on the ground in Helsinki, near your mother's apartment building. When we are in position, I will give you the signal. Your performance will be the trigger. The moment the song ends, we move. Your job is to create the biggest, most emotional, most talked-about television event of the decade. Your performance must convince Koskinen of one thing: that you have completely broken down. That you are no longer a threat, but a pathetic, shattered man who is about to confess everything on live television. You will make him believe his only option is to silence you permanently, but first, he must secure his leverage—your mother—by moving her. The moment his men move her, my team takes them. And we get your mother."

"And the song?" Aksel asked, his voice a dry whisper. Croft gave a thin smile. "That, Ari, is up to the artist. Make it count."

There was only one choice. The song that had started it all. The raw, a cappella video he had sent on a whim, fuelled by cheap wine and a life of quiet desperation. The song that had summoned the ghost of Ari from his cage. "Hallelujah".

The night of the Grand Final was an explosion of light, sound, and manufactured hysteria. In the dressing room, Leo was bouncing on the balls of his feet, his face alight with pure, unadulterated joy. He was about to live his dream. Aksel sat in front of his own mirror, his face pale beneath the stage makeup, and carefully inserted the tiny earpiece. It was invisible. He was a soldier, wired for his final mission. He and Leo were called to the stage. They stood side-by-side as the host whipped the crowd into a frenzy. The voting lines were open. It was time for their final solo performances. Leo went first. He sang a soaring, triumphant ballad, his voice clear and full of youthful hope. He was flawless. The arena erupted in a storm of adoration. It was the performance of a winner.

Then it was Aksel's turn. He walked to the centre of the vast stage. There was no stool this time, no guitar. Just him, a microphone, and a single, stark spotlight. He nodded to the musical director, and a lone piano began to play the song's iconic, mournful arpeggio. He closed his eyes, not for effect, but to centre himself, to find the core of the man he had become. He was Aksel, the son who loved his mother. He was Ari, the bookkeeper who knew the crimes. He was the finalist, the national treasure, the bait. He was all of them. He took a breath, and the voice that came out was not a performance. It was a prayer.

He sang the opening verse with a heartbreaking fragility, the story of a secret chord, of a baffled king. He sang of love and loss, his voice cracking with a sorrow so real and profound that a hush fell over the entire arena. This was not the cold fury of his previous performances. This was the sound of a man utterly broken. This was for Koskinen. He sang the verses about seeing her bathing on the roof, her beauty and the moonlight overthrowing him. His voice swelled with a desperate, remembered passion, and he knew his mother, wherever she was, would understand he was singing about a love that could not be broken.

Then, as the song reached its emotional peak, he felt a faint crackle in his ear. Croft’s voice, a calm, disembodied whisper, cut through the music. *'We are in position. Koskinen's men are outside her door. He's taking the bait.'* The final verse. Aksel’s eyes snapped open, and he stared directly into the camera, into the soul of the machine. The fragility was gone, replaced by a terrifying, righteous fury. His voice soared, raw and powerful, no longer the sound of a broken man, but of an avenging angel. "I've told the truth, I didn't come to fool you," he sang, the words a direct accusation. "And even though it all went wrong / I'll stand before the Lord of Song / With nothing on my tongue but Hallelujah!" He held the final, monumental note, his body a conduit for every ounce of pain, rage, and hope from his impossible journey. He poured it all out, a single, sustained cry of defiance that seemed to shake the very foundations of the arena. He held it until his lungs burned, until the world dissolved into a blaze of white light, and then, as the note finally died, he fell to his knees, his head bowed, the sound of his own ragged breath the only thing left in the silence. It was done. The signal was sent.
